Dear Senator Colston
I refer to your letter of 21 May 1990 concerning new subsection 44AA(2) which was inserted in the ACT Juries Ordinance 1967 by the Juries (Amendment) Ordinance 1989.

New section 44AA makes it an offence for an employer to dismiss or injure an employee, or alter an employee's position to the prejudice of the employee, because the employee is summoned to serve as a juror. The section goes on to provide that if all elements of the offence other than the reason for the employer's action are proved, the onus of proving that the dismissal, injury or alteration was not because the employee was summoned to serve as a juror is on the employer.
While I appreciate the Committee's concern with criminal offence provisions that reverse the onus of proof I believe that such a provision is justified in this case.

Jury trials are an essential element in our criminal justice system and members of the community who serve as jurors perform a vital public duty. They should not be subject to any danger of victimisation or prejudice in employment by being required to serve (in some cases for an extended period) as a juror.

Under section 44AA of the Ordinance the prosecution must prove all elements of the offence except the reason for the employer's detrimental action in respect of the employee. The reason the action was taken is peculiarly within the knowledge of the employer and in the absence of a provision along the lines of section 44AA(2), it would be very difficult, if not impossible, for the prosecution to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the action was motivated by the requirement to undertake jury service. It should be a relatively straightforward task for the employer to discharge this onus if there are reasons, other than jury service, for the action that was taken.

In cases like this where it is clear that the offence provision would be ineffective were the onus not reversed in relation to an aspect of the offence, it is contrary to the public interest in law enforcement to deny such a reversal.

Section 44AA(2) of the Ordinance is in similar terms to section 69(2) of the Juries Act 1977 of NSW. It is also consistent with section 334(6) of the Industrial Relations Act 1988. Section 334 makes it an offence to dismiss or injure an employee or alter an employee's position to the prejudice of the employee because of membership of an organisation registered under the Act or of the other matters listed in the section. Offence provisions relating to prejudice to employees who appear as witnesses which contain reversal of onus provisions to similar affect are also to be found in a number of Commonwealth Acts including the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Act 1988 (s49) and the Biological Control Act 1984 (s51).

In these circumstances, and particularly having regard to the important public policy considerations involved, I consider section 44AA falls within the very limited category of exceptions to the general rule that there should not be a reversal of the onus of proof in respect of criminal offences.
Yours sincerely
(Michael Tate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges-Whether evidence to Estimates Committee B in May 1990 in relation to asbestos in Royal Australian Navy ships was misleading, having regard to information which was available to the Navy concerning dangers associated with asbestos, and, if so, whether any contempt was committed.

Mr President, at the Estimates Committee hearing on 14 May 1990, I submitted a written question directed to the Department of Defence and to the various Services. My question was answered approximately two weeks later in writing.
The question I asked dealt with a matter of great importance, and it was as follows:

Has the Department or any of the Services done or are doing any studies into asbestos? Have the studies concluded how many are expected to die from asbestos-related diseases? What is the short-term and the long-term plan for asbestos-related diseases and the like in Army, Navy and RAAF?

That question was answered, as I said, a couple of weeks later. When the response came back from the Department of Defence, it was headed up with a restatement of my question. The restatement, in fact, contained two areas where the meaning of the question had been changed.
Part A of the question was changed from `studies into asbestos'' to ``studies into asbestos-related diseases', and part C was changed so that it no was longer grammatically correct. It read:
What is the short term and the like in Army, Navy, RAAF.
That was clearly a typographical error. The response of the Navy was:

A) Navy has undertaken a number of studies over the last six years quantifying the asbestos hazards existing in RAN ships and establishments so that appropriate action, if any, could be undertaken. Navy maintains a register of asbestos workers currently serving. Navy has not undertaken any epidemiological or clinical studies into asbestos.
B) No such studies projecting expected mortality have been undertaken.
Passing over some details of the current Defence Instructions, the answer continued:
. . . asbestos workers are subject to medical surveillance in accordance with National Health and Medical Research Council guidelines.
The paragraphs that follow form the crux of my complaint. The Navy response continued:

In the mid-1960s, the UK research in the Royal Dockyards pointed out the relationship between asbestos work in the dockyard and asbestos related disease. When this became known, the RAN adopted protective measures against asbestos from 1966.

Because most HMA Ships contained asbestos, and large numbers of RAN personnel have served in those ships, any attempt to identify all who might have been exposed would require massive resource allocation. Because of the assessed low risk, and likely low yield from such a process, it has not been pursued.
Instead individuals make their claims for compensation in the normal manner.

Mr President, to give the Navy its due, it at least covered about half a page of typewritten answer. The Army managed to spit its answer out in two short sentences, and the Air Force appears to me to have taken the question in a more serious and detailed manner. Nevertheless, at the time I got that answer from the Department, I believed that to be the truth.

I was convinced that, as a result of research in the Royal Dockyards in the mid-1960s, the Royal Navy had informed the Royal Australian Navy that there was a relationship between asbestos-related work in the Dockyards and asbestos-related disease and that from that time on-1966-and because of that information, the Australian Navy adopted protective measures. That, Mr President, was my understanding of the answer.

However, when I sent some of those answers out to other people, a Mr Ben Hills of the Sydney Morning Herald contacted me and said that he was in possession of some letters which made it quite clear that that answer was misleading. I would like to draw to the attention of honourable senators the first of the letters which Mr Hills sent to me for attention.

This letter is dated 19 October 1943-I repeat, 1943-20 odd years before the Navy claims to have put protective measures in place as a result of the United Kingdom research. This letter is signed by the Secretary of the Victorian Public Health Department and is addressed to the General Manager, HMA Naval Dockyard, Williamstown, Victoria. The reference is asbestos panelling.

I do not propose to read the whole letter. It refers to work being done in the dockyard fitting asbestos panelling into naval ships and the question of the possible harm to the health of people engaged in that occupation. The Secretary of the Department, whose signature is not decipherable said this:

There is no doubt that the inhalation of asbestos dust may produce damage to the lungs, the condition being known as ``asbestosis''. This condition, which may be incapacitating, may take years to develop, the time required depending, among other factors, on the concentration of dust in the air breathed. Usually in industry a period of about 7-12 years more or less continuous daily exposure is required to produce the condition. A case has occurred with as little as one and a half years of exposure.

The letter talks about `confined spaces', `the processes of sawing and hammering', `quantities of dust' and `lack of ventilation'. It adds that `the concentration of dust in the air breathed may become considerable'. The letter goes on to say:
The use of dust respirators may be advisable. The decision as to this would depend on determinations of the dust concentration and the degree of continuity of the work.
The letter concludes:
This Department would be agreeable to carrying out these determinations.

Clearly, the Navy accepted that offer and I have a letter, dated 9 February 1944, from a Mr Mackie, the general manager at the dockyard at Williamstown, writing to the Secretary of the Public Health Department in Victoria, acknowledging receipt of the letter of 5 February 1944 and enclosing the report of tests taken on the use of asbestos panelling. That reporttold the Navy the number of dust countsit--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who did the report?
—The report was done by the Department of Health in Victoria.
—Not by the Navy, but by the Department of Health. I'm glad we've established that.
—And the Navy, which had the information, just as it had the information, it claimed, from the United Kingdom in--
—Go back and look at the question you asked. You asked: Which studies did the Navy do?
—Is that the line the Minister is going to take?
—Well, that's part of the relevance.
—That is particularly devious.
—No, it is not. You listen.
—Order! Senator Ray.

—Mr President, I will leave honourable senators to decide whether they are going to accept the legalistic view of the Government in order to try to defend people who were given a question, took it on notice and very carefully gave an answer to the Parliament. I do not intend to quote continually from this report. However, I will quote just two or three paragraphs. The first couple of paragraphs state:

SPEECH.PARA: A number of dust counts of the air in the breathing zone of men engaged on different activities in the Table Room and the Cinema Room of a ship being refilled were made on January 5th.
The results showed that the concentration of asbestos dust in the air in certain cases was above that which is regarded as a safe limit for continuous exposure.

There are a number of parts of the report which then talk about the effect on lungs and questions as to the period of exposure. The report then refers to a study of 1,512 workers conducted by the British Silicosis and Asbestos Medical Board and the results of that study. The report then goes on to talk about an elaborate investigation by the United States Public Health Service carried out in the asbestos textile industry. As a result of these investigations, the authors suggest that 5 million particles per cubic foot may be regarded as a tentative standard. The report then goes on to table the dust counts found in the investigation at the dockyards on 5 January 1944, all of which were above the acceptable limit.

Finally, the report wound up saying that, on the basis of the American report, one might expect that a small percentage would show signs of asbestos after working continuously in such atmosphere for two or three years, and it gave recommendations for how the problems might be avoided, such as: open air where practicable and ensuring that all port holes are open. It recognised that some work in confined cabin spaces would be necessary and that, in those cases, dust concentrations might be such as to require the use of respirators, even though the work lasted only a short period, and that dust respirators would help to prevent further exposure. That material was available to the Navy. It was very detailed material, and I find it extraordinary that the Government would apparently seek to suggest that it was not relevant to the answer which was asked of the Department.

We then move to the 1970s and, obviously, the Navy still remembered that it had those studies and had presumably taken some action as a result of those studies since 1943. I do not have evidence as to what measures it took. It certainly knew what measures it was supposed to take. It knew what were dangerous dust levels. It knew that there were ways of protecting people from that dust.
I refer to an undated letter, from the Navy Office to the Secretary of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia in Balmain, which starts:
I refer to your letter of 20th July 1971. . .
Therefore, one presumes it was some relatively short period after 20 July 1971. In paragraph 3 of that letter, the Navy Office said to the Union:
It is agreed that there is a health risk in handling asbestos.

This has been recognised in dealings between various Unions and this Department since at least 1943 when exhaustive tests on dust concentrations during certain processes were conducted by the Victorian Public Health Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not on its own sailors.
—I thank the honourable senator. The letter continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The present safety instructions on the handling of asbestos which had their beginnings in these tests have been constantly under review and are considered satisfactory:

One wonders: does the Minister for Defence consider that the tests, which have been constantly under review since the 1943-44 correspondence, can be classified as studies? Obviously, there is a very careful use of language there, and I am surprised at the Minister being prepared to defend that. The letter continues:
The department is in any case doing its best to phase out the use of materials containing asbestos and considers that within the near future exposure to asbestos hazards will be reduced to a minimum.

We know that that was not even true because at the end of the 1970s when HMAS Brisbane was refitted a black ban was imposed by the workers in the Garden Island dockyard. So naval personnel were being required to remove asbestos, in my view, without adequate protection. That, however, is another matter which can be dealt with at another time, or would be dealt with at another time if the inquiry which was announced yesterday by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) was intended to go back into history. However, the Government is very keen only to inquire into current matters and not look back into history.

Mr Deputy President, as I said to the President in my letter dated 15 August, when looking at these answers and the background material that has now come into my hands, we have to have regard also to the fifteenth report of the Committee of Privileges and the comments made by the Committee concerning misleading evidence. I remind honourable senators that that related to a complaint by Senator MacGibbon over answers given by departmental officers from the Department of Defence in relation to the Project Parakeet development.

In that report it was in fact found that there had not been a deliberate misleading of the Senate. However, the Committee pointed out that all witnesses giving evidence to Senate committees should be aware of the need to avoid giving evidence which could be misleading. I believe that the answer to the question was misleading in that, by failing to refer to the Navy's pre-1966 knowledge of the dangers of asbestos, the answer tended to leave a false impression in the minds of the recipients that the Navy had become aware of the dangers of asbestos only in the mid-1960s.

As the President said yesterday, while he made no judgment on the matter, he agreed that it was a serious matter, not a trivial one, and he agreed it was a proper matter for giving precedence of referral to the Privileges Committee. There is no other remedy reasonably available to deal with this situation. We are talking here about a department which had a Privileges Committee inquiry on its answers not very long ago. The Department would be well aware of the fact that it is not to give misleading answers.

On many occasions I have found in the past that when people who are knowledgeable about defence matters have seen some of the answers which the Department of Defence has given in the Estimates Committee, they have been concerned at the failure of officials to give open and full and frank answers. Instead they use legalistic responses, such as the Minister is now attempting to put to the Senate.

The first test in 1943 was done for the Navy by the Victorian Department which acknowledged by letter that it was prepared to undertake the test. The understanding from the letter of 1971 is that those were studies which were held by the Navy and done on its behalf. Consequently, I have moved this motion so that the matter can be resolved by the Privileges Committee. This Parliament cannot operate if officials are able to so word considered written answers to questions taken on notice after weeks have passed.

If we cannot rely on full and frank answers to questions of national importance, such as those about the health of our soldiers, sailors and airmen, then what sort of a job can a senator do in the exercise of his or her public responsibility? We cannot accept and be seen to accept officials attempting to hold information back from honourable senators in the exercise of their duty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reference of any issue to the Privileges Committee is very serious. It is absolutely essential to establish a proper prima facie case before this chamber refers an issue on. It is not a party matter, so today I am not just addressing the Opposition and the Australian Democrats; I am also addressing people on my own side of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: If I thought there was any case to answer at all I would want this matter referred to the Privileges Committee for full investigation. But today Senator Newman has not put up one aspect of a prima facie case for the misleading of the Senate. That is what she is arguing about-that the Senate has been misled, implying that it is deliberate, but even saying it could be inadvertent. I say to this Senate that not only has it not been misled deliberately but also it has not been misled even inadvertently.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—Senator Michael Baume has already made up his mind, on a conscience vote, without listening to both sides-he has made that quite clear-so he should not interrupt.

SPEECH.PARA: What this is about-and what people should try to resolve in their own minds-is process; it is not about content or the morality of asbestosis and the use of asbestos. It is an entirely different issue. It is about whether an officer in the Department of Defence has set out, inadvertently or deliberately, to mislead the Senate in an answer. I want to go through carefully and analyse the question and the answer to show that that is not the case, and that there is not even a prima facie case.
One of the key paragraphs in the answer that Senator Newman relies on reads as follows:

In the mid-1960s, the UK research in the Royal Dockyards pointed out the relationship between asbestos work in the dockyard and asbestos related disease. When this became known, the RAN adopted protective measures against asbestos from 1966.

That simply happens to be a statement of fact: when the report became known, the Royal Australian Navy adopted protective measures. It does not imply that there was not pre-knowledge, or other knowledge, about problems with asbestos prior to 1966. That part of the answer is absolutely correct.

What this debate comes down to is not that anything in the answer is wrong-not one thing is wrong, there is not one act of commission in the answer that happens to be wrong-but that, as Senator Newman has said, by an act of omission the question has not been fully answered. One of the keys to that is in her own question. I hope I have the right question here-I am subject to correction, as I would hate to think that I am reading out the wrong question. She said:
Has the Department or any of the Services done or are doing any studies

That is the key to it-`has the Department done', not whether the Victorian Health Department, or someone else, did, but `has the Department done'. The answer given here is truthful; it lists when the studies have been done by the Services or by the Department. It does not list whether someone else overseas, or some other Victorian department-which, I must say, on reading the documents, showed enormous prescience on this issue, and one wonders what happened to this Victorian department's work for 20 or 30 years-carried out a study. Senator Newman has quoted from a letter to the Williamstown dockyard in 1943. Apparently, any officer answering a question on an issue has to have knowledge of what happened in 1943, but I will come back to that point.

I want to go to the timing of the answers. Senator Newman said there were weeks in which to provide answers. Most honourable senators who were here will recall there was a very restricted time between the Estimates Committee B meeting and reporting to this chamber. The sequence of events is as follows: A question was received on the fifteenth, the financial planning area sent it on to the Royal Australian Navy on the sixteenth, the Navy received the question on the seventeenth and replied on the same day. It was cleared by my office, having waited for the more tardy Army and Royal Australian Air Force responses, on 22 May and sent on to the Estimates Committee on 23 May.

I have interviewed the officer responsible for preparing this answer, and he did what was proper. He went to the existing files in the Department. He went right through the existing files and based his answer on what was in them. I admit, he did not go to archives and spend six months going back to Federation, but nor would I or this chamber expect an officer to do that. Had he done so, he still may have found nothing because the other interesting thing is that the sort of document Senator Newman is talking about today-that is, a letter to a dockyard manager-comes from the Victorian archives file, not from the Commonwealth file. We have no record of it that we can find with the Navy. We do not even know whether the manager of that dockyard ever sent the letter on properly to the Navy, or binned it or anything else. We have no knowledge in that area.

What Senator Newman is really doing is asking the question: has the Navy done a study? Because the Victorian Health Department in 1943 did a study-not commissioned by the Navy-that is not on our files, Senator Newman accuses an officer of deliberately misleading this Senate. What nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of misleading.

—Yes, of misleading this Senate. What absolute nonsense. I know that to some extent Senator Newman has been misled by Ben Hill's approach, because what he says is that he asked for all the individual files, he alleged a report exists and when we do not release the files he says we are sitting on a document which we have never acknowledged and cannot find. Senator Newman has been a victim of that sort of clever journalism, and that is a pity.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to go on and look at the actual position of privileges because, obviously, this particular one would relate to Privileges Resolution 12C that was carried by this chamber about two years ago. It says:

A witness shall not give any evidence which the witness knows to be false or misleading in a material particular, or which the witness does not believe, on reasonable grounds, to be true or substantially true in every material particular.

The key phrases are `knows to be false' or `does not believe, on reasonable grounds, to be true'. I want to go quickly back over this question. The question was asked: has the Navy done any studies? The answer comes in, and is accurate, listing the Navy's studies. But because a study is done in 1943 or, more to the point, a letter is produced, and we have the letter here, it is hardly a study-and I think Senator Newman would acknowledge that-some officer producing an answer in 1990 is supposed to have the corporate knowledge.

The critical thing is that this letter was lost to the corporate knowledge of the Navy, otherwise, one would have to ask oneself why it did not do anything in particular about it. Of course, one of the reasons is that this occurred in the middle of World War II. But to come into this chamber and say that there is a misleading answer, based on the fact that some officer has not gone back through the archives for six months to find this letter-if it exists, because it came out of the Victorian health archives-is an absolutely ridiculous proposition.

Some people may say, `Look, the problem has been raised, it is a bit hard to determine who is right and who is wrong in this chamber so why don't we send it off to the Committee, and it can sort it out'. That is an easy thing for us to do, but Senator Newman should remember that the serving officers who she wants to drag before this Committee will not regard it as some minor thing to be shoved off the agenda because it is too hard to make an intellectual decision today. That is a career-breaking opportunity for them if they have to appear before the Privileges Committee. One which will not affect their careers--

TALK.START.PARA: —McIntosh survived very well.

—My problem in this case is this: as Senator Durack knows, I am not bad at defending the indefensible, but what really worries me is having to defend the absolute defensible and not knowing whether I can do the job well enough. In this case, I am defending the absolute defensible. That is what always worries me in these cases- that people do not ever listen to the facts.
—You have very selective vision, Senator.
—Senator Newman says I have very selective vision. Once again, I am going to help Senator Newman to go back to the question that she asked. Put very simply, she asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Has the Department-
that is, the Department of Defence; we are agreed on that-
or the Services done or are doing any studies . . .

This answer is truthful. It lists what is being done. Senator Newman has produced not one piece of evidence to suggest that the Department has done any other studies. The only evidence she has produced is that the Victorian Department of Health was active in this area. I acknowledge that it was. The other point that Senator Newman should realise is that there is no link between the Navy and these issues in the current files. If there were, they would have been referred to.

TALK.START.PARA: —You weren't listening. You must have only one ear as well.
—Then explain it again.
—What about the letter of 1971 from the Navy to the union referring to the 1943 study? The Department can go back until 1966 and yet they can't give me information about 1971.
—These files, as Senator Newman knows, go back to the early 1980s. The officer--
—He went back into the 1960s.
—No, he did not. His reference and material from the 1960s were continuing information contained in the files of the 1980s.
—And there were letters of the 1970s referring to it. So what happened to them?
—They are not in the files of the Department.
—You seem to have a problem with files; and that is not my problem.

—No, I do not have a problem with files; I have a problem in that, if every one of SenatorNewman's 20,000 questions asked means a total and complete search of Navy records back to the year 1900, that is the end of the Defence budget. Today Senator Newman has not produced any case whatsoever to indicate that there has been a misleading answer. Not one scintilla of evidence has she put forward to back up her claims.

SPEECH.PARA: We now come to the motive for raising this matter. Is it, as Senator Newman says, just because we have to protect the Senate Committee and its propriety? If this were really a serious matter she would not have been on the radio bleating about this issue in advance of referring it to the Privileges Committee. If she had been serious about it--

TALK.START.PARA: —This week, when I wrote to the President.
—This transcript is dated 17 August.
—August 15 is my letter.

—This is dated 17 August. Senator Newman had to give it pre-publicity. She could not do thedecent thing like most people and just refer it to the Committee. She is still claiming that it has taken up to three weeks to get the answer; she knows it was eight days.
—It was two weeks.
—No, it was not. It was referred on the 16th and received by the Committee secretariat on the 23rd-one week later.
—We got it on the 28th.
—I am not concerned about whether the Estimates Committee secretary passed it on straightaway; I am telling Senator Newman how the Department turned it around-and it turned it around quite properly.

SPEECH.PARA: I said to Senator Newman yesterday that if I believed there was a case to answer I would be the first one to support its referral to the Privileges Committee. I also state for future reference that this will continue to be my attitude. But here we have a question asked and a question properly and absolutely accuratelyanswered. I have no doubt that the Privileges Committee would make that finding.

We do not have one supporting piece of evidence for a prima facie case. If no prima facie case has been established, then this should not go to the Privileges Committee because of the unnecessary strain and stress it places on people. That is absolutely the case. The reference to the previous reference of the Privileges Committee was quite strange. That had a much stronger base and yet it was dismissed by the Privileges Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am astonished at the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). It seems that he is suggesting to the Senate that there is no corporate knowledge within the Royal Australian Navy; that everything known is within the knowledge of only one of the more recent entrants to the Navy. Some personnel have served in the Navy for 35 or more years.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not satisfied with the Minister's explanation. It is quite clear that theNavy's corporate knowledge extends back to the mid-1960s. It could recall that it got the information from the United Kingdom. It could tell us that it instituted measures in 1966. That was quite a precise date. But it seemed to be unable to remember that it had any sort of dealings on asbestos and hazards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not `dealings'. `Studies' is in your question; not dealings, knowledge or anything else-`studies'.
—The Minister relied very heavily on corporate knowledge.
—Because you asked that question. We can only answer your question.

—I am drawing to the attention of the Senate the fact that the corporate knowledge was clearly able to go back as far as the 1960s and yet it could not go back to the early 1970s, when reference was made to the verydetailed studies that the Navy received in the 1940s.
—What studies?

—The study that the Victorian Department of Health did on behalf of the Navy, which the Minister ridicules on the grounds that the Navy cannot find the report. Seemingly, the Victorian Health Department has a much better ability to keep records. It is amazing that Victoria can produce reports that it did in the 1940s and yet the Navy cannot produce the report which was provided to it. I remind honourable senators that I pointed out that, on the basis of the study of 1943, continuing dust measures--
—What studies? One letter.
—It is a study.
—It is not. We will table the letter so that everyone can look at it. It is not a study; it is a letter putting views forward-good views.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, would you call the Minister to order? The President is already in receipt of these documents. They are available and will be made available to the Committee. I am not trying to hide anything. It is a detailed report giving measurements which I chose not to read out to the Senate but which are available for honourable senators to peruse. There are detailed studies of the total fibre count and the total dust count in the various parts of the ship studied on 5 January 1944. If the Navy has a problem with filing, that is the Minister's problem, not mine. But the Senate should not be diverted from the essence, which is that the material was available--
—To whom?

—It was, and had been, available to the Navy. One presumes that it has not also lost the letter of 1971 that refers to the studies of1943-44. The Navy has also done tests since then based on the 1943 material. It seems as though the corporate knowledge of the Navy is rather selective. I am astonished that the Minister would use that as a basis of an attempt to divert the Senate from the real purpose of this, that is, when questions are asked of officers of departments, honourable senators are entitled to expect full and frank answers. In this case the answer given was clearly intended to assure honourable senators that the Navy became aware of the hazards of asbestos dust in the 1960s and that, when it became aware of the problem, it instituted health measures.
—Don't criticise them for not providing an answer to a question that wasn't asked.

—I am interested in the Minister's interjection because the Navy answered as it chose. Havingchosen how it will answer the question it is then expected to answer it in a manner which is not misleading. It chose exactly how it would put its words. I did not put those words into the Navy's mouth. Having put those words down on paper an honourable senator is entitled to expect that they are the full facts of the matter. The use of the words which the Navy gave to honourable senators gave a clear understanding that that was when it became aware of the hazards of asbestos and that that was when it introduced measures. The clear evidence is that it became aware of it in the 1940s. It was told then what measures to introduce. It subsequently conducted tests. We do not know whether it put measures in place. After all, there are 300 applications before the Department of Veterans' Affairs in regard to asbestos related diseases from people who have war entitlements.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an important matter. It is not just a question of semantics. The Minister has tried to run this debate on semantics. He has tried to ridicule it by reference to what one might expect of corporate knowledge. I expect the Navy to know when it became aware of asbestos and its dangers, and when it was introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not ask that question.
—I asked them, `What studies?' and they gave me an answer which was--
—Ask that question and you will get the accurate answer. You did not ask that question.
—Is Senator Ray claiming that it is perfectly all right for an answer to be misleading provided it is giving additional information that does not directly relate to anybody's question?
—They have to accurately answer your question and they did so.

—If Senator Ray is saying that, it will be a very poor day for this Parliament when any witness can come before a committee and volunteer additional information which is misleading. That, obviously, is the crux of what he is claiming. I am sure that the Senate will reject that utterly. We absolutely cannot be prepared to accept misleading information whether it is in direct answer to a question or in supplementary material provided in answer to a question.
—But there is no misleading, is there? You know that.

—It is totally misleading as the additional documents which I have presented to the President make absolutely clear. I therefore urge honourable senators to support my motion to refer this matter to the Privileges Committee for resolution.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Newman's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this reply to the Budget Speech I want to address how the Government's policies have destroyed the capacity of Australian business to be internationally competitive, with dire consequences for all Australians. There is a growing recognition that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, who seems to so dominate this Government, is taking Australia down a path to disaster. The longer it continues, the worse will be the result, the harder will be the recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer has lost all credibility. No-one believes him any more. Unemployment is now rising, with 100,000extra job losses since last October, bankruptcies soaring and small businesses failing in ever increasing numbers. Yet we live in a region of great opportunity. The opening up of economies such as Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand offers new and exciting opportunities for Australian investment and trade. But we have to be competitive. The Japanese, Taiwanese, Americans and Europeans, just to name a few, are all in the same markets.

Unfortunately for Australian business, the economic parameters set by this Government produce almost impossible obstacles. Australian business must compete in the face of economic liabilities such as an overvalued dollar, forced up by interest rates often double that of our competitors; higher rates of inflation; inflexible labour conditions bearing little relationship to productivity or profitability; expensive and sometimes inefficient transport; an uncompetitive waterfront; exorbitantly costly coastal transport; stifling government regulation; and so on. All these factors are beyond the control of business but within the capacity of government to vary.

These obstacles to business efficiency, as I said at the outset, have destroyed much of our competitive export capacity and our import replacement potential. So month after month we see the mind-boggling figures of our current account failure as we plummet further and further into debt. We have a debt of $150 billion and rising-an incomprehensible figure. It is not all government debt; that is true. The accumulated debt of the Commonwealth and the States is about one-half of that figure, but it is debt because Australia cannot produce competitively the higher value goods and services which we demand to maintain a higher living standard with the added burden placed on our business as compared with our neighbours.

Those neighbours are, at best, bemused. I remind the Senate of the comments of Singapore's Prime Minister, Lee Kuan Yew, on the Lateline television program recently. When he was asked what he thought of Australia 25 years ago, he said that 25 years ago he had thought of Australia as a wealthy, advanced nation as compared to its neighbours in the Asia-Pacific region. `Now,' he said, rather politely, `you are not so advanced'. He is right. Our neighbours have moved ahead. They, on the one hand, have industrialised, upgraded and poured energy and determination into designs, innovations, advanced technological research and strategy. We, on the other hand, have failed to take advantage of the running start that our generous natural endowments have given us. We still find ourselves excessively dependent on primary commodities.

Others seek to seize potential advantage from our relative decline. I refer, for example, to Taiwan demanding the political price of Australia allowing China Airlines to land in our country in return for direct flights to Taiwan, which we now need more than it does. The irony is that, 25 years ago, if Australia was an advanced nation, Taiwan was an aid recipient. Today, as I said, Australia has an enormous foreign debt of $150 billion-on some indices the third highest in the world-whilst Taiwan, with virtually no natural resources, has a foreign reserve of some $US75 billion, the second highest in the world.

Other countries further to our north look at us with disdain. On the other side of the ledger, those with funds to invest, such as Japan, Taiwan and the countries of western Europe, are discouraged from doing so in Australian industry for the same reasons as are crushing our capacity to export. They run into exactly the same obstacles and choose to invest elsewhere. We are a small market, so what is produced here must be produced at an internationally competitive price and must be of internationally competitive quality.

Again looking at the example of Taiwan, over the next five years it will invest between $US5 billion and $US10 billion overseas; but on Australia's current economic path most of that investment will go to the United States or South East Asia. We will not attract our share. We have just seen the recent example of the China Steel Corporation, which has rejected the opportunity to invest in a new steel mill in Australia, notwithstanding the protective legislation passed by this Government. This simply demonstrates the point that I am making. It seems that the Corporation is now more likely to go to Malaysia because of its better economic environment.

Consequences will flow from this economic decline. As we become economically weaker we become vulnerable in so many ways. In the area of defence we will lose the technological edge that we have over so many in the region because we will not be able to keep up. Our capacity to support the elderly, the sick and the disadvantaged will be reduced. Unless this economic decline is arrested, it will change the very nature of our society. We will become less secure in so many ways.

In the face of this dire predicament the Opposition seeks to be constructive. Dr Hewson last night set out a new direction for Australia in order that we might again become a major economic force in the region. I remind the Senate of the program he set out-a program to boost our production, our productivity and our exports; to reduce the overall tax burden by real cuts in government spending; to simplify the personal tax system at lower rates to restore incentive; and to shift the burden of taxation away from income towards consumption in order to encourage savings and to provide scope for the elimination of various taxes on exports and business inputs.

It seeks to free up the labour market in order that we might get internationally competitive wages outcomes which tie wages to performance and genuinely protect the interests of workers; to implement industry reform which will cut protection which is simply adding costs to those industries which are not protected; to privatise government enterprises in order to produce competition and real efficiency gains; and to provide a new efficient infrastructure through reform of telecommunications, road and rail transport, aviation, shipping and the waterfront.

Through this package the pressure on interest rates can be reduced and Australia can return to the track of eradicating inflation. We can then start to give our producers a fair chance. The fact that it is so critical that we remove the government-imposed or maintained obstacles to internationally competitive production was expressed with great clarity by Dr Hewson last night when he said:

If we are to stabilise our foreign debt by say, 1995, we need to shift nearly 4 per cent of our production into exports . . . even if we matched the best performance of the post-war period we would not see our debt stabilise this decade.

That is only a question of stabilising the debt, let alone starting to reduce it. In the same way as Dr Hewson has sought to be constructive in the Opposition's overall program, coalition senators in this place, within their areas of special interest and responsibility, will set out how things might be different and better with the objective of restoring Australia's prosperity and properly meeting government responsibilities.

In that spirit, I want to look at the desirability of better locking Australia into our regional opportunities. Our share of the trade among the Association of South East Asian Nations is still only 2 per cent, so there is a great deal of room for improvement even in our near region. I suggest that the Government should put much more effort into bilateral trade relations. So many eggs have been put into the basket of multinational negotiation. Whilst there is no doubt about the laudable economic objectives of that strategy and the higher political profile gained from such international fora, bilateral opportunities have gone begging. I will look at two case studies which I put to the Senate for its consideration: that of Indonesia and, the one that I mentioned earlier, Taiwan.

I suggest that Indonesia provides a good case study in the process of neglect. In a program of major structural adjustment, necessitated by overdependence on oil export earnings, combined with falls in the prices of oil and other commodities, Indonesia undertook a series of major reforms to remove an anti-export bias in economic regulation and to encourage investment. The result has been rapid economic growth, based on expanding export industries in a range of manufactured and semi-processed goods. This process has been taking place over the last five years, but Australia has done little to prepare to take advantage of the new opportunities being created.

A trade and commercial development program booklet from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) published in June 1990 at last recognises that the opportunities presented by Indonesian growth warrant a higher priority in Australia's trade and commercial policy and market development efforts, but the measures proposed are meagre and the suggestion that `foreign competition in Indonesia is starting to intensify' is laughable. Our competitors have been putting years of arduous effort into joint venture development backed by billions of dollars in government support.

The booklet suggests that Austrade should develop a market development strategy for Indonesia. It is surprising and deplorable that there is not already a fully developed long-term market development strategy in a country which is one of our nearest neighbours with a market of 180 million people, an economy with significant resource development potential, and where there have been signals for at least three years that reforms and structural adjustment would lead to rapidly expanding opportunities.

Among the proposed measures, it is suggested that we should `explore with Indonesia the early inclusion of a double taxation agreement' to foster trade and investment and, in particular, joint ventures. This implies that in June 1990 we had not even begun to explore a fundamental prerequisite for joint venture development.

The 1989-90 budget for DFAT shows clearly the priority attached to such objectives. The corporate plan of the Department said that we would seek `to improve investment and trade flows through closer liaison and assistance to the private sector to the extent that resources permit'. The rider is, of course, bureaucratese for an intention to do nothing.

Fortunately, the Australian privatesector has not waited for the Government to discover the expanding opportunities in Indonesia. Exports to Indonesia in the financial year just ended are expected to reach $1 billion, having almost doubled from three years ago. Australian mining companies have also been active in joint venture developments in the minerals and energy sectors in Indonesia. Opportunities won for participation in joint ventures in mining are expected to add $350m to Australian investment in Indonesia by 1992.

It is pleasing to note that this significant share of joint venture opportunities was said by DFAT to have been greatlyassisted by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau funded Indonesia-Australia geological mapping project which commenced in 1976 under the Fraser Government. It concluded last financial year. It is less pleasing to note that no steps have been taken to develop new project activity in that sector.

Mining is a sector in which Australia has considerable comparative advantage and is, therefore, an efficient supplier and where Indonesia has considerable potential for growth which, given Indonesia's good record in income distribution, can be expected to alleviate poverty. It is, therefore, good aid and, at the same time, it is good trade. It is often the case that good aid makes for good trade. Economic rationality dictates that we should not give away goods and services that we cannot sell competitively in a free market.

The other case study I mentioned and to which I wish to refer is Taiwan. Here also Australian business is to beapplauded for its efforts, despite the Australian Government. With negligible support, the Australian-Taiwan commercial relationship reached nearly $4 billion last year. It is interesting to note that that is almost double that of our relationship with the People's Republic of China, into which this Australian Government has poured enormous resources.

The Australian Government has demonstrated itself to be incredibly naive. A year ago, in this chamber, honourable senators might recall Senator GarethEvans describing the trading relationship-I stress trading relationship and not political relationship-with Taiwan as something we have to `tread carefully and sensitively' on. At the same time, trade between Taiwan and China was rapidly building. That is the naivety. Last year it almost reached $3.5 billion.

Qantas Airways Ltd does not fly to Taipei, but Cathay Pacific does. As honourable senators will know, Cathay Pacific is part owned by the People's Republic of China. As a matter of interest, so do another 19 international airlines fly to Taipei, and China Airlines flies to 18 international destinations.

It is believed by the Australian Chamber of Commerce that that direct air link would lift tourists from Taiwan to Australia from some 20,000 to over 130,000 a year. It has been a saga of poor negotiation and lost opportunity of which this Government should not be proud. Two billion dollars is the extra value put on the direct link by the Australian Chamber of Commerce.

The whole relationship is a sad story of Australian companies hindered by lack of information regarding commercial opportunities and contacts, lack of Government assisted promotion, clumsy visa facilitation and, as I said, an absence of direct flights. I have used these two examples to make a point, but there are many others that one could choose. Even if the domestic economics were put right, this Government is still far from maximising Australian business opportunity in the region.

The Government, for some reason, seems to have a mindset against the role business can play in restoring our competitive productivity. When Australia played a pivotal role last year in the setting up of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference, which had its first ministerial meeting in this city, no role for business input was built into it. Government and its bureaucrats know better. That body-now the most important regional economic body-has had itssecond ministerial meeting. Despite the protests of the Pacific Basin Economic Council and others, there is still no role for business. How can effective regional economic cooperation happen in isolation from commercial realities?
John Hewson said last night in his address:

What we need now is to harness all the energy and determination of the Australian people to reach our objective of making Australia once again a significant force in our region of the world-a strong Australia that can hold its head high.

We have slipped back so far. If the Labor Government is not going to acknowledge its failures and make the necessary policy changes, at least the coalition is committed to giving the Australian people a fair chance.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes before lunch yesterday devoted to the second reading debate on the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill I was highlighting, amongst other things, the way in which the national maritime museum project demonstrates the incompetence not only of this Federal Government but also the previous Wran Labor Government in New South Wales. To recapitulate on some of the points I made, this Bill provides for the establishment of the AustralianNational Maritime Museum at Darling Harbour in Sydney. The Bill also outlines the functions and powers of the museum and provides for the establishment of the Museum Council to replace the interim council.

SPEECH.PARA: The establishment of this museum will undoubtedly be of great benefit to the people of Australia. It will be a repository for a very important part of Australia's history, namely our maritime history. As an island continent, seafaring and maritime history has been of great importance to the development of this country; and shipping continues to be of great importance to our economy-something that this Government does not recognise, as demonstrated by its continued failure to do anything about reforming the waterfront and coastal shipping. But, of course, that is a matter for another day.

This project largely began as a creature of politics. It was created as a ploy in the 1984 New South Wales State election. From the outset, it has been manipulated to further political ends. The decision to establish this project was taken when the Wran Labor Government was facing that election. It wanted to develop a significant project as part of its Darling Harbour baby. An agreement was reached with the Hawke Labor Government, in time for Mr Wran to go to the polls in March 1984, to the effect that the Federal Government promised to provide some $30m to construct the maritime museum. That figure was based virtually on conceptual plans which had not been developed in great detail. Many people involved in the project have acknowledged that the $30m was nothing more than a guesstimate of the cost of constructing the museum. As a result of agreeing that the Commonwealth contribution would be $30m, the Wran Government and Laurie Brereton, the then State Minister responsible for Darling Harbour, virtually signed an open cheque to get the project off the ground. Their fast- tracking of the Darling Harbour development in total led them to sign that open cheque.

The $30m was not only based on conceptual plans but also related only to the cost of the building. One can question the competence of the people who reached the agreement but ignored the fact that further money would be required to establish the museum once the building had been constructed. Right from the start, this project has been fraught with controversy and difficulties as a result of the combined administrative incompetence of two Labor governments-the former New South Wales Labor Government and the Hawke Government, which continues in office.

As a result of industrial disputes and the design being developed in more detail, over the years the cost has blown out to about $70m-$40m above the original estimate. In no way can that blow-out be sheeted home to the New South Wales Greiner Government. It is the combined product of industrial disputation and the need to carry out detailed design work which had not been done when the original Commonwealth contribution and estimated cost of $30m was agreed.

The project was originally due to be completed in time to be opened in October 1988 as part of our bicentennial celebrations. However, it was not ready then because of delays in construction, partly due to industrial disputation. It was then due to be opened in September 1989, but it was not ready then. More recently, we were told that it would be opened in December this year, but we have been further advised that it will not be opened until the latter half of 1991. Again, we see the difficulties that have been associated with this project.

One reason for the continuing delay has been the blow-out in costs from $30m to $70m, resulting in a dispute between the New South Wales Greiner Government and the Federal Government about who is to meet the additional costs. The fact that the Federal Government has not agreed to contribute additional significant funds to meet that cost is, in our view, a severe dereliction of duty. Under the spirit of the agreement reached in 1986, the Commonwealth was to provide the funds for the project. The Federal Government agreed to provide $30m which was to be the full cost of the project. Clearly, in terms of principle, the present cost of $70m ought to be met by the Federal Government because it is no fault of the State Government that the cost has blown out to $70m. Despite protracted negotiations, the Federal Government refuses to meet that responsibility and, until recently, the New South Wales Government refused-rightly-to hand over to the Commonwealth Government for use as a museum a building which it was responsible for constructing.

The Federal Government refused point blank to continue negotiations on the additional $40m cost. It was interested in litigation rather than negotiation. It threatened the New South Wales Government that if it took the matter to litigation, won its case and the Commonwealth was required to provide the additional $40m, the Federal Government would simply knock $40m off the annual Commonwealth grants to the New South Wales Government.

These are the sorts of blackmailing and standover tactics to which the Commonwealth Government has resorted in its dealings with the States-so much for the promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to renegotiate the compact with the States later this year to give a better division of responsibility. This Commonwealth Government treats the States with absolute disdain. We have seen that again in the Budget which was presented this week. Yet again, this Government refuses to cut its spending on its programs but it squeezes the States, local government and statutory authorities, trying to present a facade of a Budget in which spending is cut. The States continually suffer at the hands of the Federal Government. The Australian National Maritime Museum is yet another example of the way in which the Commonwealth Government treats the States with complete disdain.

The Commonwealth Government refuses to negotiate. Finally, under the threat of a reduction in funding, the New South Wales Government has acquiesced and agreed to hand over the building to the Commonwealth Government so that the museum can commence operating. The New South Wales Government believes that it is in the interests of the people of New South Wales and Australia to get the museum up and running. This has been a sorry story of the attitude of the Federal Government and the incompetence of the Federal Government and previous State Labor Government in New South Wales.

There has been controversy about not only funding but also members of the museum Council. Early in 1988, the Federal Government sacked three key members of the Maritime Museum Council, leaving it without a Chairman or Deputy Chairman. The three people sacked had particular expertise in maritime history-the Chairman, Mr Alex Dix, who was also Chairman of the National Museum of Australia; the Deputy Chairman, Rear Admiral Andrew Robertson, who convinced the Government of the efficacy of establishing a maritime museum; and Miss Kristine Klugman, who had spent eight years on the trust of the Australian Museum in Sydney. They were sacked by the then Minister, the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), and were replaced by lackeys of the Federal Government, including Mr Peter Doyle, who is a mate of the Prime Minister; and Trish Kavanagh, the wife of Laurie Brereton, the former State Minister responsible for Darling Harbour and the museum project. The potential independence of the Council was thereby compromised.

Other members of the Council strongly protested about those sackings at the time and sent a telex of protest to the Government about them. Those who signed that telex were Professor Geoffrey Boulton, Professor of History at Murdoch University; yachting journalist, Mr Bruce Stannard; and merchant mariner, Mr John Evans-the three other members of the Council at that time. Obviously, they recognised the way in which the Government was seeking to undermine the effectiveness of this Council through the appointments that it made. That has been a further matter of controversy as far as this project is concerned.

There were also difficulties with the legislation as it was first presented to this Parliament. Its provisions relating to the destruction of items regarded as no longer required by the museum were inadequate. The previous Opposition shadow Minister responsible for this area highlighted that particular shortcoming and was able to negotiate with the Government amendments to the legislation. We certainly welcome those amendments taken at the initiative of the Opposition which will tighten up those terms with regard to the destruction of items.

The second inadequacy originally with the legislation was that there was no requirement for directions which the Minister might give to the Council to be tabled in the Parliament. Again, the Opposition sought to have the legislation amended to ensure that ministerial directions had to be tabled within six days of being given, if they were to remain valid. Again, we welcome the Government's agreement to that amendment, which will certainly improve the legislation. It is important that parliamentary scrutiny be maintained with regard to directions that a Minister might give to a council, particularly when, as I have said, the Government has put some of its lackeys on that council.

However, the Opposition has a further difficulty with this legislation. Subclause 30 (2) provides that a person who has reached the age of 65 cannot be appointed as a director of the museum; nor can anyone who is appointed director have the term of that appointment continue beyond the time when he will turn 65 years. This is a clear example of age discrimination which is completely unacceptable to the Opposition. In this day and age, I find such a reference to age grossly offensive; more than that, the nation simply cannot stand by and watch age used as a barrier to employment. With the ageing of Australia's population, we need people to remain in the work force and to remain productive as long as possible. Therefore, the Opposition wants to see clause 30 struck out of the legislation.

I understand from advice we have had from the Government that that in turn creates difficulties with regard to the Comcare legislation, in terms of the capacity of Comcare to cover staff of statutory authorities beyond the age of 65. The Comcare legislation will therefore require amendment to take account of that. That is why, rather than seek to move this amendment in the Committee of the Whole, we will seek the reference of this Bill to the legislative and general purpose standing committee that is relevant for its consideration. I understand that the Government has agreed to that. We hope that from that committee consideration appropriate decisions will be taken which will allow this clause to be removed from the legislation so that age does not remain a barrier to appointment to the position of director of the museum.

The coalition has a very firm policy with regard to age discrimination and indicated in our policy on aged people at the last election that we would in fact legislate to prevent age alone being a bar to employment. It is a very important issue to us, and we hope that the legislation will be appropriately amended and that any consequential amendments to other legislation will be initiated.

When the museum does finally open, the problems that I have already detailed with regard to its establishment will continue in other forms. We have had difficulties with funding not only the construction of the project but also its continuing operation because the initial funds that it was expected would be provided for the continuing operation of the museum have been severely cut.

That has resulted in there being no facilities for staff or for storage, no library and no room available in the museum for volunteer attendants. It also means that space that was to have been used originally as the education area has had to be given over to house the United States-Australia Gallery as a result of what one must say is certainly a very welcome gift from the United States-a bicentennial gift of $6.25m to establish this gallery of the history of Australia-United States maritime links. Certainly that will be of benefit to the museum, but it should not have been done at the expense of education facilities.

It also needs to be recognised that while we do have some historical maritime links with the United States, we have perhaps more important maritime links with Britain, the Netherlands or even with France. Yet, in the objectives of the museum, only the link with the United States is mentioned. It appears that only that link will receive attention in the museum's exhibits-certainly in terms of any special treatment.

Many people who are experienced in this area believe that when the museum does open, in many respects it will be in an almost unworkable situation. The Government has determined it is going to be an exhibition-oriented institution rather than a national collecting institution, and one can question the validity of that decision. However, the major crisis facing the museum is one of staffing. Most visitors to museums only see the attendants, but the effectiveness of museums is determined by the backroom staff, by the curators, by the education officers, by the conservators, and by the administration staff.

A letter from the former Minister, Mr Punch, confirms that staffing for this museum, originally expected to be 110, will in fact be cut back to something like 75. That will create extreme difficulties for the operation of this museum particularly with regard to collection management. It means that some conservation activities on the part of the museum will have to be contracted out, which in the long term could well prove to be more expensive than retaining staff. It is, as I understand it, proposed to reduce curatorial staff from 16 to just four, and that underlines the mismanagement of the development of this project.

Another issue of controversy has been the relationship between this national maritime museum and the Sydney Maritime Museum. On the one hand, it seems that even despite these cuts in funding we have the national maritime museum with still some considerable funding but no ships. On the other hand, we have the Sydney Maritime Museum, which is a community based museum, with a significant number of historic ships but very little in the way of funds. Negotiations between these two bodies have been conducted over the last few years without any successful agreement being reached in terms of either the capacity of the national maritime museum to take over the exhibits of the Sydney Maritime Museum by paying a reasonable price for those ships which the Sydney Maritime Museum holds, or leasing those exhibits so that all of the maritime history of Australia could be collected in one central location. I believe that is also certainly a shortcoming with regard to the development of this museum.

All in all, the development of this project has been a very sorry saga indeed. Let us hope that after the passage of this legislation that sorry saga will not continue, that this museum will develop on a very positive basis henceforth and provide the benefit to the Australian community of which such a project is capable. The issue raises very serious questions about the competence of both this Government and the Wran Labor Government in New South Wales. It raises very serious questions about the bona fides of this Government in terms of its relationship with State governments. Those are questions that really need to be addressed. Let us hope that with the passage of this legislation the museum can develop on a much more positive basis than has been the case up to now. It is on that basis that the coalition will support the legislation with the reservation that we will have it referred to the relevant legislative and general purpose standing committee for consideration of the age discrimination issue. Let us hope that when the legislation comes back for further consideration in this chamber that factor has been properly dealt with and that will no longer be a barrier to our support to the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Would you refer to Mr Brereton as Mr Brereton?

As a taxpayer in New South Wales and as a senator for New South Wales I understand why the State Government had to give way on this matter, pay the $40m and also meet, I think, half of the $3.5m cost relating to defects and completion costs which are to be shared by the Commonwealth and the State. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill is to establish the Australian National Maritime Museum. Senator Bourne, of course, spoke on behalf of the Australian Democrats.

The function of the museum will be to exhibit historical material in cooperation with other public and private institutions.
