SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, as this is the first time I have spoken when you have been in the chair, I congratulate you on your appointment. We look forward to this whole chamber and particularly the Committee of the Whole being excellently chaired by you.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the Bill that is before us and strongly support the creation of the Australian National Maritime Museum. It will be a valuable acquisition to Australia and to all Australians. Indeed, it will be a very important acquisition internationally. It is a first-class investment by Australia, both in capital terms and in recurrent terms.

My colleagues have already referred to political machinations and inefficiencies and overbidding in contracts. I do not wish to place any blessing on those deficiencies when I talk about this being a good investment, but I do not wish to be distracted by the mistakes of the Labor Government in New South Wales, or indeed the present Federal Government, in the conduct of this matter from looking at the broader picture, which is that, fundamentally and money matters aside, this is a very sound investment by Australia. It is one that I very much welcome, as, I am sure, do all honourable senators.

It is important not only for this generation in this decade but, I believe, for many generations to come. It is to be placed, quite rightly, in the most accessible and enhanced part of Sydney Harbour-Darling Harbour. I still hold the vision in my mind of going to the celebrations in Sydney Harbour on Australia Day 1988. As a South Australian, I freely acknowledge the excitement that I shared with so many thousands from all over this nation at the proper re-enactment of all that we can rightly be proud of in 200 years-Sydney Harbour being the first place of European landing and settlement in Australia-of the use of that excellent port and magnificent city. It is in this place that the national maritime museum is rightly situated.

I say that, having experience of the South Australian Maritime Museum in my own city of Port Adelaide. Prior to the establishment of this national museum, the South Australian Maritime Museum was established, with good foresight and bipartisan support on the part of the State Parliament. Indeed, the foundation Director of that excellent facility, Dr Kevin Fewster, has already been appointed as Interim Director of the national maritime museum. I have no doubt that, when the Interim Council becomes the full Council by this legislation, he will be endorsed as the continuing Director under the terms set out for the Director of this national maritime museum. Kevin Fewster has a particular personal contribution to make, given his experience in South Australia, his particular accumulation of skills and his knowledge of this whole field, to which I wish to refer in terms of its various parts.

There is, then, undoubted value in this maritime museum. Let me say why I think that. At least half a dozen themes can rightly be included in a museum of this kind. The first is Aboriginal involvement with the sea. A second is the European voyages of discovery to this country. A third is immigration. Many Australians, until very recently, came here by ship. The transition from their original place of birth to their eventual destiny was by the sea. A fourth theme is commerce and trade. We cannot use the word `trade' without it conjuring notions of ships and of going down to the sea. We have also the theme of the Australian fishing industry, a still underdeveloped but important industry in this country.

Of course, we have the naval defence of this country and all that comes to mind when we think about the long history of the Royal Australian Navy. It is important to understand the role of the Navy in terms of the defence of this country, not only in repelling any future invasion-hopefully, we will not have any such experience-but also in protecting Australian and allied interests on the basis of international law and justice, exemplified in the three ships that are now in the Persian Gulf. We have the traditions of the Navy, but I will come back to that later.

Another theme is leisure and sport. I know that athletics, football, tennis and hobbies, such as art and photography, have been enthusiastically pursued by many generations of Australians. Other popular leisure activities include water sports, such as sailing, swimming, surfing, surf lifesaving and even the completely aimless activity of mucking about in boats. There ought to be a place such as the national museum in which Australians can record and celebrate their involvement in such activities. These themes will be incorporated into this national maritime museum.

Tens of millions of dollars have been invested in the museum. The museum will be constantly available to the public. It will be, of course, a major tourist attraction for international visitors as well. I have a vision of this museum being not only a great national asset but one that will rival any other such institution in the world.

I believe that this museum, which is being created in formal terms by this legislation, has the prospect of being the best maritime museum in the world. It will be located in one of the finest harbours in the world-Sydney Harbour. I note that already a great deal of planning has gone into this museum which, I trust, will be opened before the end of this year. But before this can happen, this legislation has to be adopted by the Parliament.

My colleagues who have spoken before me have already talked about the most unfortunate political situation that has delayed the start of this building and the acquisition of exhibits for display. I do not need to repeat the summaries that Senator Chapman and Senator Michael Baume have already given. Rather, I will concentrate on the positives of the present and the positives of the future. I want to ensure that in this debate we do not overlook the really fundamental perspective-that by passing this legislation we will be establishing a major national asset.

I wish to recognise the fact that Dr Kevin Fewster, the deputy directors, Gavin Fry and Quentin Howarth, and all of the staff of the museum, have, on an interim basis, made very careful plans not only for what will be exhibited and where it will be placed in the many spaces that will be available in the building but also for the design detail of these displays and how they will be sold to the public. I wish them every success in putting those well-made plans into place. As we see these plans taking shape there will be considerable excitement for them and for all of us who have an interest in this museum.

I briefly outlined earlier some of the themes that will be exhibited in this museum. We cannot do enough to excite Australians-not just Australian school children but adults of all ages as well-about the original Aboriginal involvement with the sea. I refer here to Aboriginal craft and fishing as well as maritime food sources, knowledge and language.

We cannot excite Australians enough about the history of the discovery of Australia-the voyages across the Indian Ocean and the Pacific Ocean; the voyages from various European points of departure to Indonesia which instead reached our coast.

Australians need to know more about the voyages that were undertaken to India, South East Asia and the Far East. They need to know why some of the Polynesian and Melanesian islands were given such religious and exotic names. The museum will help us understand more about navigation and ship design. We will be able to learn about the actual sequence of events that led to Australia's discovery and settlement in the context of all the other nations in the Pacific.

Of course, at the pinnacle of this aspect of our history is Captain James Cook. Although Cook is well known to all school children and indeed, every Australian, he is still little understood. My good friend, Sir Geoffrey Badger, a former Vice-Chancellor of the University of Adelaide, quite recently wrote an excellent book about the discovery of islands in the Pacific. The core chapters in this book are about Cook. I am proud that the museum will concentrate on this area of our history in terms of European voyages of discovery.

With regard to immigration, we ought to see exhibits on the theme of convict transportation to Australia, as well as the free settlers who pioneered this country. What was their experience as they travelled to Australia by sea? What about sponsored immigrants, particularly following the Second World War? What were their hopes and aspirations for a new land, for a new discovery and for new prosperity? Even more recently, the tragedy of Indo-China has led many, at the risk of their lives, to flee communism and other evils as boat people and come to this country.

I will not say more about commerce and trade or the Australian fishing industry. But I wish to make one further reference to the Royal Australian Navy. It has already been acknowledged that a major impetus to the establishment of this Museum has come from the Australian Navy itself. The Royal Australian Navy, which has a proud tradition, has, over many decades, kept many items of historic significance.

A great proportion-I believe the heart-of this collection is being given for safekeeping to the maritime museum. I am sure that in the decades ahead every serving seaman and officer in the Australian Navy will be frequent visitors to this museum. The museum will provide a link between their current experiences in serving this country and the past and this will reinforce the traditions which are proudly held by the Navy and by all Australians.

With regard to leisure and sport, those of us who find pleasure in sailing competitively, such as my wife, my children and many of my friends-whether it be in mirrors, sharpies, herons or one of the other 50 classes of competitive yachts sailing on our bays, inland waterways and lakes-will be able to use the museum as a point of reference to see historic yachts exhibited.

I note that the most famous competitive yacht that brought considerable fame and glory to this country in the America's Cup 12-metre class, about which we were all so excited in 1983, will be exhibited in the museum at Darling Harbour. I note that the United States, as its major gift to us in celebrating our Bicentenary in 1988, gave us many items of significance that illustrate the naval or marine connections between our two countries. The United States' gift will be, I understand, a permanent gallery in the maritime museum.

Also New Zealand gave to us a gift of a yacht, the Akarana. I have been happy to inspect this yacht. It is beautiful to look at. It is built in the old style and, moreover, it was rigged in 1888-exactly 100 years before our Bicentenary. It has been completely refitted, is in total working order and sails on a monthly basis at least on Sydney Harbour.

If I may express one small personal aspiration, I hope I might be amongst the crew on Akarana one day. It is certainly a bicentennial gift from New Zealand that we treasure, and it is one that I am sure the National Maritime Museum will look after most carefully.

But there is a wider number of items in the fleet. This is not just a static museum; it is a fleet which includes a destroyer, Vampire; it includes a patrol boat, Advance; it includes the very important World War II commando raider, Krait, which was working behind Japanese lines near Singapore in the 1940s. I have been happy to see these vessels and to know that they are in the keeping of the National Maritime Museum.

We have a traditional Indonesian sailing boat, the Sekar Aman; we have a refugee-carrying fishing boat, the Hong Hai; and I have already referred to the 12-metre yacht, Australia II, and to the New Zealand 1888 gaff-rigged racing cutter Akarana. I will refer to just one more boat and that is literally the world's fastest boat. It happens to have been made by an Australian and driven by an Australian. It is, of course, the jet-powered Spirit of Australia. This boat is not only the fastest boat in the world, but was built by the individual hard work of an Australian in his backyard. I think that it is a point of inspiration for all Australians to be able to come to such a collection of items that relate to the sea, and then to find that there is virtually a whole harbour full of actual boats of particular significance.
I note that in the tenth edition of the interim Maritime Museum's quarterly newsletter Signals, No. 9, the Director, Kevin Fewster, says:

The Museum has many programs being developed on what has always been a very tight schedule, but people here are working very hard towards that great day when we open our doors to the public. Everyone has in mind the key objective, and I know we will get there with a product of which we all are very proud.

I might appear to be a publicist for what is one of the great acquisitions for all Australians, the national maritime museum, and I accept the charge. I am enthusiastic about this centre, and I note that the enthusiasm is shared by all those that I know who are connected with any of the seven or eight themes relating to maritime matters to which I have already referred.

I make it quite clear that in respect of the Director, deputy directors and staff of the interim museum there has been no involvement in the political machinations that have gone on about the building or in the financial disputes between the Australian Government and especially the former Labor Government of New South Wales. I wish to free them from any of the taints and accusations that have so much stalled the beginning of this very important venture. I also want to place very clearly in this debate a record of their personal and professional enthusiasm for getting this museum as quickly as possible into a completed state. They just need the key to open the front door and they will be, I believe, serving us all very well in a professional capacity.

In my remaining few remarks I wish to have it noted that the legislation that is before us provides sensible flexibility with regard to the museum's commercial arrangements. There are powers set out for the museum, that are in the hands of the Council, to make contracts, to determine all manner of direct commercial arrangements for the operation of the museum with standard formulae. But I note that there is flexibility for the museum itself to contract research and for the museum, through having an acquisition annual budget, to recover items of significance to our maritime history.

I wish it to be seen that, as long as there is full accountability and as long as there is full sensible subscription to a three-year plan and to annual working plans, there ought not to be any sense of bureaucracy impeding the entrepreneurial initiatives that the Director and others on the staff and Council of this museum can take up on behalf of all Australians. I, of course, highlight the provision in the legislation-not as some administrative order-for a three-year strategic plan and for annual operational plans that will be approved by the Minister, tabled in parliament and subject to continuing monitoring and comment by elected members of parliament.

I also foresee an involvement with private sector partners. I believe that it is in the very spirit of Sydney that entrepreneurs can work in tandem with the maritime museum. For example, harbour tours might leave from the museum waterfront and visit parts of the harbour, traverse under the Sydney Harbour Bridge and visit even at least some small part of Kirribilli-at least some small part of Kirribilli that they may have access to-and the museum's cross-harbour moorings near North Sydney.

I encourage the museum, right from the outset, to call for bids of interest and to explore possible contracts with independent operators who could take up this advantage, so that visitors to the museum could spend their time looking at the various shapes and sizes of exhibits. They could then board a collateral entrepreneur's boat at regular times for a valuable additional insight into the harbour and items of significance on the harbour.

I also note that this is not to be a static museum, but hands-on-participatory. It is to be dynamic, in the best tradition of anything that has begun in the area of museums in the 1990s. I wish to encourage this participatory collection. Wherever possible, visitors-especially young Australians, school children-when they go to the museum should not just to be told, `Don't touch. Walk only on this line. This is only for you to see'. We should maximise what visitors can actually handle and participate in, and so gain all the more enrichment, enjoyment and involvement.

I therefore conclude most happily by commending this legislation, of course with the Committee reference and the amendments that my colleagues have referred to that would improve the legislation. I believe this will result in a magnificent new acquisition for all Australians. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to the speeches in this second reading debate to some extent in reverse order. First of all, I thank and congratulate Senator Teague for his very positive contribution to the debate. It was a welcome contribution and I make only one particular comment on it, which is to share his views about the Akarana. I had the great pleasure of welcoming it to Canberra on behalf of the Australian Government, and it looked great on the lake. I was upset that it was taken away and put back on that other lake in Sydney. That disappointed me because it would have been a substantial contribution. I welcome the things which Senator Teague had to say.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chapman and Senator Michael Baume raised a number of other matters, most of which are on the record. They have spoken about them and their rhetorical flourishes are recorded for posterity. But there are some matters of substance to which I think I should respond in the reasonable manner in which they raised them.

On the question of the finances of the building, I should say for the record that settlement has now been reached on funding the completion of the building. The sum of $2.04m was provided in the current Budget as the Commonwealth's contribution for completion and rectification of the building. That is now a settled question.

Senator Chapman raised some concerns about the potential problem with storage facilities in the new building. Perhaps I should advise him that the Australian National Maritime Museum's administrative headquarters is only 100 metres away from the new building. That will be housing staff, the library and conservation and storage of the collection, so there is a separate and adequate arrangement for that.

He made some points about staffing. I should simply point out for the information of the Senate that the curatorial staff is, in fact, 10 and not four. With the number and quality of those people there will be a strong intellectual core. While continuing to meet the Government's priority, it has been made clear by the Government that it will be primarily an exhibiting institution and will have a substantial exhibition role.

I also would not want an impression to be left that there is some spirit of conflict between the Sydney Maritime Museum and the new Australian National Maritime Museum. The current relationship, as I am advised, is harmonious. In fact, negotiations are very well advanced on agreement on display arrangements.

I was concerned about one of Senator Michael Baume's remarks not about the project itself but about problems in the United States (US) of America in terms of attitude to the project. I am assured that cooperation continues to be excellent with the United States. United States institutions have been willing to contribute display items for the United States gallery. There is a consultative committee on which the US Consul-General is represented and, through this, the US Government is being kept informed of developments regarding the Museum. There are also close and direct links already established with the US Information Agency Exhibits Service, which is providing valuable support. While I am sure that Senator Michael Baume has met with some individuals who have expressed concern-I am sure he would not raise that matter lightly-broadly, I think the level of relationship remains positive and good.

I endorse the remarks that Senator Michael Baume made about the challenges which have been met by the staff in developing this museum and, like him and all other senators, I thank those staff for their excellent contribution.

I should also say something about Senator Bourne's contribution. She might have set an example for other senators. She worked out what she wanted to say, she said it and then she finished. It may have taken some of her colleagues by surprise because it is not something which is common. I hope it is not a habit she loses through experience. I hope that she does not learn some of the less precise and concise habits of some of her colleagues, and certainly not some of her erstwhile colleagues from the Australian Democrats who might have been renowned for going on a little longer.

I should also make a comment about an important matter. Although it is not important in the second reading debate, it is the one outstanding area of amendment about the problem of the age limit. I note that that is a matter that will properly be discussed in the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. It will be interesting for me to be associated, for the first time, with a Bill about to go through that process, and I hope it proves to be very worth while.

I simply comment that I note the views expressed by Senator Chapman. The legislative and general purposes committee is the appropriate place to deal with the substance but, having noted his views, I simply want to say on behalf of the Government that, as he raises a very important issue about age discrimination, I do not want to deal with it lightly. We also do not wish to deal with it in an ad hoc way. It is not a matter that is unique to this Bill. It is a very broad question of government policy. It has been a policy of all governments of both political persuasions for a long time. That does not mean it should not be changed; it simply means that the change needs to be studied and planned and the implications considered before changes are introduced.

There are reasonable arguments for the point of view which Senator Chapman put. The Government would not like to see changes made in a short term, ad hoc manner simply by an amendment to the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill. Rather, there should be a more broad and comprehensive approach. I thank honourable senators for their contributions and for their support for the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Budget that was brought down by the Government this week I wish to make a few comments about how I believe it was wrongly formulated and has a poor basis for its calculation. It may sound rather trite to be stating that this Budget is being received at a time of grave difficulty and uncertainty for Australia, but it is the truth and simply cannot be emphasised enough.

SPEECH.PARA: It is equally important to recognise that the fallout from the Middle East crisis worsens, but in no way causes, the underlying problems that we are experiencing today. The central economic fact facing Australia today is the failure of the policies of the Hawke Labor Government. The runs are simply not on the board, and the predictions are not coming right.

This is the eighth Budget that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, has put down for the Hawke Labor Government and it will be the eighth time that he has got the figures wrong. He has got the figures wrong for the last seven consecutive Budgets, and there is no indication whatsoever in this Budget that he will be right on this occasion.

We are looking back to a current account debt of $21 billion for 1989-90, predicted by the Treasurer 12 months ago to be $18 billion. A combined external debt of $156 billion, five times that of 1983, requires 29 per cent of our export returns simply to service it. That also translates as a payment of $25 per month from each Australian family.

We all well know that Australian families can afford no more under this Government; they are stretched to the limit. Businesses and private individuals are going to the wall at unprecedented rates. Australians can simply have no confidence that this tired Government is displaying the political will, let alone the track record, to shift more national effort into exports.

The only tool of economic management that the Treasurer seems to understand is manipulation of interest rates. Even now, when interest rates have been pegged back, the real interest rate against inflation has not fallen one jot. This Labor Government has never seemed to appreciate the importance of getting down inflation to make Australia more competitive. A rate of 7.7 per cent in the June quarter of 1990 has to be compared with 2.3 per cent in Germany, 2.5 per cent in Japan and 4.4 per cent in the United States of America. By any comparison we are performing badly.

As we digest the latest predictions of the Treasurer, we should remember that two years ago he was confident of a 3 to 4 per cent inflation rate by 1990. Our current rate of 7.7 per cent is no better than that for the same time last year and a 6 per cent rate is all we can dare hope for under this Government. That is a disgrace.

If we want grim proof of what is happening to the Australian economy, we need refer only to the bankruptcy statistics for the past financial year. With 9,131 bankruptcies, we are suffering an 11 per cent increase on 1988-89. There were 1,195 bankruptcies in Western Australia-a rise of 34 per cent on the last year. And the Treasurer has the audacity to tell us that they are a lovely set of figures and that Australia is on track. As I have said before, Labor's policies work even better in the west! The June quarter showed a 26 per cent rise in bankruptcies over the previous 12 months with a 56 per cent rise in Western Australia.
The figures speak for themselves. This is not a case of an Opposition criticising for the sake of criticising; these are the figures and they cannot be disputed.

The same evidence of failure emerges from the decline over the past 12 months of 8 per cent in total private investment and a decline of 13 per cent in investment in plant and equipment. When investment levels drop over four successive quarters we have a major problem, but one that this Government has not been anxious to tackle.

It comes back to the central problem of the need for export productivity. Levels of investment in tradeable commodities are below 50 per cent, compared with 58 per cent when this Government took office in 1983. Whereas in the years from 1963 to 1983 the level of investment in export and export competing industries was 60 per cent, it has held at 51 per cent under the Hawke Labor Government.

This Government cannot evade the criticism made by such former senior advisers as Mr David Charles and Mr David Morgan. On 2 July Mr Charles stated that unless Australia moved away from its mistaken macro-economic policy of high interest rates, any micro-economic reforms would be negated. Mr Morgan also has flatly contradicted the Treasurer's excuse that the flood of imports is being caused by massive industry re-equipment. That is simply not true. The figures I have cited in regard to declining investment also make that fact obvious.

Instead of a Treasurer who is prepared to be unpopular through taking hard decisions, we simply have a Prime Minister-in-waiting who uses VIP aircraft to sustain a new-found interest in Australian Rules football and who centralises the pre-Budget lockup in Canberra so that the media are subject to the maximum of personalised disinformation.

In these tough economic times, the Treasurer should not be flaunting his entitlement to take a plane load of journalists to a football match. Many people in this country are going bankrupt. Many people are losing their jobs because of this Government's economic policies. Yet the Treasurer has the audacity to take a VIP aircraft from Canberra to Melbourne and back so that he can watch a game of football.

With the drift of Labor policy and leadership, it is significant that on 14 August one of Australia's greatest experts on public opinion, Mr Gary Morgan, called for an end to the `government by public opinion' that has contributed to economic difficulties. But no, this Government will continue to govern by the polls.

What the public expects from the Federal Government is action on its major concerns. As measured last June, seven of the 10 nominated areas were economic. It is in the hands of the Treasurer to take the tough decisions, but sadly he will not. Australians want their representatives to take the hard decisions but that is not what they are getting from this Government.

This Labor Government has come to this Budget with a recent track record of cynical populist decisions that had everything to do with winning votes and nothing to do with economic consequences. They had everything to do with making sure that preferences were transferred from the Greens. Yet, what is happening as a consequence? The Greens have been jettisoned, too. There has been the ducking and diving over Coronation Hill, where yet another inquiry was called thus preventing any possible mineral exploitation. Study after study has been undertaken not so much to protect the environment but to gather those Green preferences that got this Government so surprisingly into office in March this year.

The refusal to allow the merger of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd and the National Mutual Life Association of Australasia Ltd was a convenient exercise in business bashing to reassure the Labor faithful, but the effect will have been to hamper our national effort to achieve competitiveness in finance on the world stage. Australia invariably loses from this cynical, ad hoc process. Australians do not need to be told; they now know that.

The latest Keating Budget is very much the product of a Prime Minister-in-waiting, who may pose as being tough and responsible-he tries hard at that but fails-but who neglects to take action against the real problems that I have outlined.

Where is the action that will encourage business investment, that will provide Australians with the incentive to save, and that will lead to smaller and cheaper government? Underneath the rhetoric of self-congratulation, this is simply a do-nothing Budget of a Government running out of coverage, shocked to the bootstraps that it is back in office. It has run out of any vision. Even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), when asked on radio the other morning what his vision for Australia was, had to admit that he did not really know. He has lost any vision for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a shocking admission.

—That is right; it is a shocking admission. That is the reality and that is what we are seeing in this Budget-a government absolutely paralysed. It has been well said that if there are many bouts to fight to solve Australia's economic problems, the Hawke Labor Government is still cowering in the dressing-room.

SPEECH.PARA: There are no real prospects of lasting relief from interest rates with a 6 per cent inflation rate. The saving to revenue that may be achieved by forcing pensioners off low interest bearing bank accounts may well prevent bank interest rates from falling through the loss of bank profits.

The coalition has always welcomed a Budget surplus, but we recognise that last year's prediction was trimmed back by $1 billion and the actual surplus was $8,045m. This shortfall was caused by an additional $500m in outlays and $400m in lost revenue through failure to ensure the proper drafting of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill. We constantly see problems flowing from poor drafting of legislation and this is but another example. We can have no confidence that mistakes and pressures similar to those that I have outlined will not occur in 1990-91. Indeed, once we take away the profits of asset sales and some manipulation of State debt financing, we are looking at a real Budget surplus of $6 billion rather than the $8.1 billion that the Treasurer is quoting.

The economic indicators quietly spell out the failure of this Labor Government to take action. Business investment in 1990-91 will fall by 7.25 per cent and there will be a further fall in the household savings ratio. So much for the constant assurances from the Treasurer that the Government's economic policy is working. Once again, we are flying on a wing and a prayer with the prediction of a current account deficit of $18 billion for 1990-91.

More Australians are realising that even if another blow-out does not occur, the bottom line still points to our debt problem increasing. We will be lucky to keep inflation down to the predicted 6 per cent-double that of all our significant trading partners-as long as this Labor Government ties itself to its political masters, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and the accord that still divorces wage outcomes from the essential yardstick of productivity. Despite the trumpeting of savings in the field of welfare, spending in this area will still rise by 12.3 per cent. The reality is that Australia continues to have a big spending government with a real expenditure increase of 0.6 per cent.

Australians will have every right to be cynical about calls for restraint, and the tightening of benefits, when this Government can still find $2m in order to promote some kind of Aboriginal compact. There is always money in the can if the Government particularly wants to do something. But, unfortunately, the reality is that the Government cannot find the money for those who need it. That is what we are talking about; that is the difference. We are talking about proper targeting of money. We are not talking about taking money from people who need it. This Government has the capacity to find money to dish out to any special interest group. With regard to the Aboriginal compact, if the Government actually sought consultation with the Aboriginal communities, it would know that those communities do not want this compact in any way, shape or form.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in the Senate I was asked a couple of questions about this issue. The first question, which came from Senator Kemp, related to the Government's and my knowledge of the situation at Pyramid prior to the statement of the two Victorian Ministers on 13 February. ANSWER.PARA: Was he-
that means me-
or the Government aware of the financial difficulties of Pyramid prior to 13 February, and was he aware in advance that this press statement was to be issued?

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. In its recent report the Australian Manufacturing Council criticised the willingness of some Australian companies to adopt new design and production techniques. —Have a look at the dollar. What did the Budget do to the Australian dollar

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked a question. Senator Walters wants to have a look at the dollar. I suggest that she does that for the rest of Question Time. If there were dollar notes about I would hand her one over so that she could do that.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Devereux's question starts by referring to the Pappas Carter report on manufacturing industry in Australia. It raises a number of issues relating to that report and, indeed, the question relating to productivity and quality in Australian manufacturing industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

—As far as Senator Walters's interjection is concerned, if the best the Liberal Party of Australia can do is say that we should have cut three times more out of social security than we can and kicked every pensioner and every beneficiary in the guts, then as far as I am concerned it has no care and no concern.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. This question relates to moneys that were set aside in the 1989-90 Budget for a package of initiatives for youth arising out of the Burdekin report of the National Inquiry into Homeless Children. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEATH OF PENGUINS ON MACQUARIE ISLAND

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Defence to recent reports suggesting that a flight by a Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Hercules may have been responsible for the death of penguins on Macquarie Island. Can the Minister advise the Senate what action he intends to take in response to those reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of allegations that the death of some 7,000 penguins on Macquarie Island some time in the period 28 May to 11 June 1990 has been linked to a Hercules flight which occurred on 30 May 1990. Hercules flights to Macquarie Island are normally conducted three times a year to provide air drops of food and other supplies to the Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition base, and also to conduct any aerial survey work required by ANARE or the Tasmanian Department of National Parks, Wildlife and Heritage. The flights are provided free of charge from the squadron training hours. Several previous flights have been tasked by ANARE to deliberately overfly penguin colonies to enable census photographs to be taken. No incidents have occurred in the 10-year period in which these flights have taken place.

ANSWER.PARA: The alleged incident on 30 May was fully investigated, under the Defence Force Discipline Act, by the RAAF Air Commander and it was found that there was no case to answer. The particular aircraft in question overflew land only at the drop zone at the ANARE base on the north end of the island, 25 kilometres from the incident. Due to strong westerly winds and turbulence the aircraft was at least one mile seaward and down wind of the incident site. A previous director of ANARE, Mr Phillip Law, has supported the RAAF investigation and has stated that he is aware such incidents have occurred when rough weather has forced penguins to crush against cliffs to escape winds and waves. Neither I nor the RAAF would wish to prolong the issue by engaging in a public debate over the results of the investigation. While there is any doubt regarding the role of the RAAF in the penguin deaths, I am inclined to defer any further Hercules flights to that region.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: Is it not possible for the Government to influence the ABC in the types of programs it provides?
—I have also canvassed this issue when it has been raised.
—This is a question from Joh.

—Is the Minister for Administrative Services aware of the strident employer criticism of the recent decision to introduce parental leave for both mothers and fathers as an industry standard? Does he believe that this response from the employers is at all justifiable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter to which Senator Giles refers is one that arises from a decision of the Industrial Relations Commission on 26 July this year which was a decision handed down on the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) test case concerning the issue of parental leave. The Senate should recognise that the total amount of leave available to both parents was not increased by the test case-it remains at 52 weeks-the difference being that now it can be shared by both parents. The Government, at the Commission, supported the ACTU claim for parental leave on both efficiency and equity grounds. The Government felt, and still feels, that this will ensure that all workers with family responsibilities will be able to exercise their right to work without discrimination and without conflict between employment and family duties. We also felt that this approach would improve job satisfaction for workers of both sexes and would also, of course, improve the long term retention of skilled workers in the labour force, be they men or women.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Giles mentioned that there was a strident response to this decision. The Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) did oppose the ACTU claim on the basis of the high fixed costs associated with the hiring and training of new staff on a temporary basis. The Government's view was, and still is, that as women left the work force for periods of maternity leave, employers were left to bear the costs of hiring and training new staff on a temporary basis. The allowing of both men and women to share parental leave means no added new cost. However, it does mean that the cost to industry can be shared more broadly between employers as women and men now have the opportunity to share the time absent from the work force. The Government also considers that the take-up of parental leave is expected to be low, thus minimising the cost and inconvenience to employers.

The other aspect of the decision that should be recognised in this context is that which goes towards freeing up part time work. This part of the decision is likely to increase the rate at which parents do return to employment. As the CAI, in this instance, conceded, the freeing up of part time work provisions and awards is a cost effective and desirable move.

The Government supports the move to parental leave. We feel that the decision goes some way towards encouraging increased participation by women in the work force and also enables men to undertake a greater share of child rearing responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Will the Minister be taking action in response to the concern raised in the Australian Medical Association Journal by Ms Robyn Pritchard, director of nursing at the Overton Nursing Home, that insufficient Federal Government support is available for specialised residential care for Alzheimers disease and dementia sufferers? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of dementia is one of growing concern in the community. For example, in Tasmania the number of various voluntary organisations and community groups which are engaged in providing services and care, and indeed lobbying on behalf of those suffering from dementia, has increased. Their efforts have been very marked over the last several years. I would imagine that that is why, amongst other things in the Budget the other night, the dementia grants program has expanded from $200,000, covering seven hostels in 1983-84, to a $10.9m program covering 260 hostels providing programs to 4,607 residents. I think honourable senators will agree that that is a very necessary but very welcome expansion of those services.

ANSWER.PARA: In recognition of the increased demand for dementia programs, additional funds have been allocated over the next three financial years to enable expansion of the program. In the 1990-91 financial year, an additional $3.3m has been allocated, taking the total available for dementia grants this year to $14.4m. This will mean that 55 per cent of hostel residents suffering from dementia-that is, approximately 6,000 residents-will be able to participate in the programs that the grants provide. The additional funds allocated in subsequent years will enable the coverage to be maintained at 55 per cent. Applications for new programs submitted by organisations prior to May 1990 will be reassessed shortly with a view to funding them as soon as possible in this financial year.

Mr President, as you may expect, I have no particular brief on the specific hostel or nursing home which Senator Knowles mentioned, but I will take up her specific query with the relevant Minister after Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Treasurer inform the Senate of the results of the recent Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) measures of productivity performance in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Budget time, when the Budget is the most prominent document dissected and considered, other important documents which are published are sometimes overlooked. Since the Opposition-or the Opposition as it was, before some honourable senators went into the House of Representatives and so on-continually raises the question of productivity in Australia, I thought that it might be helpful and instructive to refer to the Australian Bureau of Statistics discussion paper which was released on Friday 17 August.

ANSWER.PARA: The ABS uses the measure of multifactor productivity. It found that multifactor productivity in Australia rose by a strong 4 per cent in 1988-89. The measure of multifactor productivity includes technical progress, improvements in the work force, improvements in management practices and economies of scale-distinct from the somewhat sterile measure of labour productivity.

Part of the credit for the rise in productivity goes to industry for lifting its investment performance and for restructuring the way in which industries operate at shop floor level. I think it is fair to say, however, that Government policy has been aimed at increasing the productivity of both labour and capital, through award restructuring and training, exposing industry to international markets, the productivity element in the wage system and so on. As an outcome of those factors, productivity in Australia grew strongly throughout the 1980s, although the Opposition-almost alone-continues to assert that productivity growth has been flat.

The remarkable thing about Australia's productivity performance is that its growth has been strong in the face of a number of factors that usually lower measures of productivity. For example, employment growth in Australia throughout most of the 1980s was very strong, outstripping production growth. This creates the impression that labour productivity is weaker than it really is.

Secondly, there has been a steady increase in the services sector as a share of gross domestic product. In Australia, the services sector is not measured in the productivity figures. That is, productivity in this sector is defined as zero for statistical purposes in Australia, while other countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development use higher figures based on the output of the services sector.

The third important factor in Australia's productivity performance is that wage restraint and the rising cost of capital have led industry to substitute labour for capital goods in the production process, thus dampening the effects of labour productivity growth and raising capital productivity. This is a very important set of statistics, and I commend it to Opposition senators for their weekend reading.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is it a fact that, in the recent Budget, the Government has introduced a scheme to put pressure on doctors to prescribe generic drugs instead of trade-name drugs and pressure on pharmacists to dispense them as well as pressure on patients to take them? Does he know that the therapeutic effect of some generic drugs is not the same as the effect of trade-name drugs? Further, does he appreciate that, for the first time, this scheme has government and bureaucracy determining what doctors will prescribe and how patients will be treated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to note that, by definition, generic drugs are required to be of the same quality, have the same active ingredients and do the same job as the brand-name drugs on the market. Of course, they have binding components and colourings which make a difference to the way in which a particular drug is presented to a consumer. But the active ingredients and medical effects are the same as apply to brand-name drugs.

ANSWER.PARA: But putting that as a preambular matter, the new policy to which Senator Herron refers is part of a series of initiatives the Government has taken to encourage the growth of the Australian pharmaceutical industry and to develop a pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) which better serves the Australian taxpayer and consumer through the provision of safe, effective and better priced drugs. Under the new pricing policy, the same drugs will continue to be available through the PBS but there will be a charge over and above the basic patient contribution if a higher priced brand is prescribed and dispensed.

However, there will be always be at least one brand available to consumers for no more than the relevant patient contributions. I am advised that the lower priced brands have undergone rigorous testing to ensure that they are of the same high quality, have the same active ingredients, and do the same job as other brands of the drug. Senator Herron would know that the lower priced brands are already widely used and accepted in Australian hospitals with patients switching satisfactorily to other brands which some doctors in the community may prescribe.

It is hoped that doctors and pharmacists will work together to protect low income patients, especially from having to pay higher prices. The Government will be making a big effort to ensure that consumers, doctors and pharmacists are informed about the policy and are reassured that the lower priced brands do the same job as their higher priced counterparts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would Senator Tate, should he require it, prefer to take castor oil or coloxyl?
—Either of those alternatives would be better than staying much longer in the chamber during Question Time.

—I ask the Minister for Defence whether it is true that 40 men left HMAS Adelaide at Garden Island, Western Australia, following the discovery during exercises between Sydney and Fremantle that their ship had inadequate protection in the event of a low air attack. I further ask the Minister whether these ships are deficient in this respect and, if so, what he intends to do about it, given the ship's obvious lack of protection in the event of such an attack in the Gulf. I also ask the Minister whether any personnel from HMAS Darwin or HMAS Success are absent without leave. Finally, I ask the Minister whether it is true that crew members of the three warships were misinformed about their likely location in the Gulf and that when they heard a radio message to the effect that they would be only 100 miles from Iraqi controlled territory, and thus within range of Iraqi missiles, morale plummeted causing a high percentage of the crew to desert their ships.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I should say is that the maritime commander has reported to me and to others that the morale on the ships is excellent. The only worry I initially had on the morale of the ships was quite obviously the fact that at the time we made the decision several people on those ships had to face a court-martial. The allegation was that that may have affected morale on the ships. On the work-up from Sydney to Stirling, any such embryonic problems were ironed out and the morale on the ships is excellent.

ANSWER.PARA: No-one on the ships has been informed directly of the operational area. It has been indicated that the most likely operational area will be in zone two, but again that has not been determined. Next week we are going to a meeting of naval nations at which a variety of decisions will be made on operational control and areas of operation. Senator Vallentine raises this sort of classic question. She is really assuming that there is some weapons platform somewhere in the world that is totally invulnerable. I would be interested to hear where it is. Any weapons platform has some vulnerability. What we have said is that although the most likely zone of operation for our ships is within the extreme outer limits of Iraqi air power, there is very little likelihood of its being exercised in that area, and logic suggests that there are far more tempting targets far closer in.

Within the assets of the Australian Navy these frigates are the ones best served to resist air attack. They have the Phalanx defence system, and a variety of missiles on board. No one can ever assert that any weapons platform is totally invulnerable. I have never really said this before, but I think Senator Vallentine has got together every rotten stinking rumour that is floating around and given it a run here. Had Senator Vallentine followed her normal practice and aired that question a little earlier I might have been able to suggest some changes to it so she did not fall into that trap.

I repeat: from every bit of evidence available to me, the morale on the ships is excellent. Not one person was forced to go on these ships. The morale and the working up of the ships has gone exceedingly well. The defence systems on the ships are the best that we have. Many other ships of like type will be operating in far closer air range with exactly the same defence systems but with different flags on them. I do not believe that Senator Vallentine has contributed much to the debate today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister to answer the first part of my question. I am genuinely seeking information about the 40 men reported to have jumped ship at Garden Island. Can the Minister please answer my question. Is this true or not?

—Firstly, I think we should clarify for the Senate that there are two Garden Islands. Senator Vallentine is referring to Garden Island off Stirling, not in Sydney Harbour. No such reports have been brought to my attention. I will investigate them but I hope that her question is based on some supportive facts and not on the first rumour that she has picked up. I will be able to determine that fairly shortly, maybe by the end of Question Time but certainly by the end of today.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Defence and concerns the command structure in the Gulf. What information has the Australian Government received and what decisions has the Australian Government made to establish a clear command structure for the military forces of Australia and the other allied countries that are already in place or soon arriving in the Gulf, in Saudi Arabia and in the whole region about Iraq? I noted yesterday during Question Time, despite all our hopes to the contrary, that the Minister was pessimistic about the likelihood of a direct United Nations resolution for military interdiction under full UN auspices in support of the blockade of Iraq. Have there been any diplomatic developments in the last 24 hours to vary the assessment that the Minister gave yesterday-and I note that this is the last sitting day of parliament for a fortnight-and what is the command structure for our ships, not only in relation to the exiled Government of Kuwait and the military of Saudi Arabia and the deployed United States forces, but also in relation to the other nations contributing allied forces to the Gulf region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is a necessity here to distinguish between command and operational control or coordination. Firstly, all Australian ships are under Australian national command. That will not be changed. Secondly, they had guidelines issued to them on Wednesday for the rules of engagement. As I have said before, whilst I will not release those publicly they reflect announced Government policy and they reflect what is required under international law. One of the difficulties we have in such an exercise is that many nations are now contributing ships. There will be a need to coordinate their activities. For that purpose, as I indicated partly in an answer to Senator Vallentine earlier, there will be a meeting next week between those naval nations which will determine who operates in which zone and which part of the zone, what the operational coordination will be, who will command, et cetera.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat what I said the other day: we would prefer United Nations command. As is typical of Question Time answers, the answer that I gave yesterday was given when I was somewhat pessimistic, but within five minutes a far more optimistic note had arrived. All I can say is that we are on the more optimistic side of the kerb now in regard to the Security Council and the resolve of people there. We have seen many false storms before. All I can say is that I am less pessimistic than I was yesterday. To reiterate on Senator Teague's question, command always stays in Australian hands. Operational control will be determined next week. Rules of engagement will bind the commanders of our ships.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Defence. In view of the Prime Minister's stated support for constructive diplomaticefforts to be used in resolving the Gulf crisis, can the Minister inform the Senate what action, if any, Australia's Ambassador for Disarmament, Mr David Reese, has taken in advising the Government on the situation and trying to bring about a peaceful resolution? Given the gravity of the situation, does the Minister believe that the services of Mr Reese could be used to help bring about a peaceful settlement of the Gulf crisis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my view, Senator Bourne's question is based on a misunderstanding of the role of the Ambassador for Disarmament. The Ambassador for Disarmament is responsible for pursuing Australia's interests in the negotiation of arms control and disarmament agreements at the Conference on Disarmament at Geneva, as well as pursuing our arms control interests in other international forums, including the relevant organs of the United Nations such as the First Committee and the United Nations Disarmament Commission. There is no direct role that the Ambassador can play in seeking to bring about a peaceful solution to the Gulf crisis.

ANSWER.PARA: The organ of the United Nations which has the major role in the handling of the Gulf crisis is the Security Council. Australia's permanent representative to the United Nations, Mr Peter Wilenski, and his staff are in constant contact with the members of the Security Council, seeking to pursue ways in which Australia can contribute to the peaceful resolution of the crisis. The Government has already made it clear that it will look for every opportunity to resolve this issue peacefully but is, of course, prepared to support the stronger action provided for in the United Nations Charter itself, should that become necessary.

I am pleased to note that implicit in Senator Bourne's question is a high level of trust in Ambassador Reese. That is a trust which, of course, my Government shares. As the honourable senator may know, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade is in Geneva today, talking with Ambassador Reese whilst they attend the review conference of the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. I am sure that Senator Evans will be drawing on Ambassador Reese's wisdom and experience in all of his discussions, including those concerned with the Gulfcrisis. In his meetings today with Senator Evans, Ambassador Reese will have ample opportunity to give his views and influence the Minister.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION ON THE RIGHTS OF THE CHILD

TALK.START.PARA: —My question isdirected to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. What is the significance of Australia's signing of the United Nations International Convention on the Rights of the Child? Does the Minister believe that there is any basis to the criticism directed at the Convention, in particular, its effect on the relationship between children and their parents?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that Australia signed the Convention on the Rights of the Child a couple of nights ago in New York. I believe it is a very significant affirmation by Australia of its willingness to adhere to the principles enshrined in that Convention. Honourable senators will know that the Convention is aimed at a worldwide expression of solidarity with infants, children and teenagers in their securing of those minimum rights which are essential to their very physical well-being and then their maturing and growing within a sociable community, but, of course, with the pre-eminent role being accorded to a family if it is a well functioning unit.

ANSWER.PARA: Unfortunately, we know that even within Australia that is not always the case and in those instances a role for state intervention, as through child welfare and other agencies where the rights of the child are paramount, is an important but, one would hope, minor role of government in relation to the usual way in which children are brought up, certainly in Australia. Worldwide there is no doubt that governments need to be confronted with a benchmark, which this convention is, against which they can be judged in the way in which they relate to children and help secure their upbringing in a sociable way as they mature.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the rights of the parents?

—Somebody just interjected about the rights of the parents. The Australian delegation to the various United Nations forums which drew up this particular convention took a leading role and had inserted certain articles and provisions to ensure that the parents, or legal guardians if parents were not available, should take that prior and pre-eminent role and that governments should support parents in that role. For example, the Australian delegation had article 5 inserted, which says:

ANSWER.PARA: States Parties shall respect the responsibilities, rights and duties of parents . . . to provide, in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities of the child appropriate direction and guidance in the exercise by the child of the rights (recognised in the Convention).
Further, article 19 provides that States which are parties to this particular convention:
Shall take all appropriate legislative, administrative, social and educational measures to protect the child from all forms of physical or mental violence, injury or abuse...
and make sure that where that occurs in the context of a family that is not functioning well, then certain action can be taken.

Whilst recognising that certain households can break down in their relationships to protecting children, the pre-eminent role of the family is recognised. That would explain why Australian organisations, such as the National Association for the Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect, which I believe has as its president Mrs Rosemary Sinclair, have been so supportive of this particular convention, as has the Young Women's Christian Association of New South Wales and the episcopal conference of the Catholic Church here in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —With reservations.

—What they have said is that whilst they support the convention, they see it as a benchmark against which Australian governments, Federal and State, will need to be judged. The press release put out yesterday by the episcopal conference said that the Catholic Church in Australia expects greater effort to be made in various legislative, economic and social supports for children as set out in that particular convention.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe the signing of this particular convention is a very important step in the securing of the rights of children, not only in Australia, but throughout the world. In that way I believe we are expressing a sentiment which is now finding favour right throughout the various nations of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I have now received the following response from the Treasurer.

The Australian Taxation Office awarded the Tax Pack contract to News Limited under a tender process. The choice of paper source was a matter for the contractor, taking into account the quality and cost specific in the contract.
