DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Short proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The actions of the Hawke/Keating Government and State Labor Governments which have caused massive losses of taxpayers money through gross financial mismanagement.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring to the Senate a matter of the most extreme public importance. It is a matter that we were going to bring up before the announcements of the last couple of hours about the proposed sale of the State Bank of Victoria and the partial privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. That has added considerable height to the importance of this matter for discussion, namely the actions of the Hawke-Keating Government and State Labor governments which have caused massive losses of taxpayers' money through gross financial mismanagement.

SPEECH.PARA: We are witnessing in Australia today the culmination of a building-up of a web of mismanagement, deceit and corruption in financial administration in this country that is unparalleled. We have seen State governments doing deals with each other and the Federal Labor Government doing deals with State governments in a way that has been designed very deliberately to undermine the confidence of the community in our basic institutions and, indeed, to undermine our basic institutions themselves-our financial institutions, the Reserve Bank of Australia, the process of government and, indeed, the whole parliamentary system itself. Never in the history of this country have we seen such an insidious, progressive and continual undermining of those basic institutions.

We have par excellence in this country Labor Inc. Indeed, it is not Labor Inc-it is Labor red ink. Everywhere we see a Labor government in office at the moment we see the taxpayers of those States being bled to death. We have seen it in my own and Senator Button's State. I am glad that Senator Button is going to be replying in this debate to the disastrous situation in the State of Victoria, a situation that has become so disastrous that today, against the expectations of any Australian, the heart and soul of Victorian financial institution-the State Bank of Victoria-is bankrupt and is being put up for sale by the State Government against every philosophy, every practicality and every pretence of decent management and government administration in this nation.

It flies absolutely and totally in the face of everything that Victoria and the Victorian Government have stood for. The amazing thing about the announcement in the last two hours that the State Bank of Victoria will be sold is that not one Victorian spokesman was involved. Not the Premier of Victoria, not one Victorian spokesman, but the Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating) made the announcement. As of one hour ago, Mrs Kirner, the Premier of Victoria, had not made one statement relating to this proposal.

This proposal potentially requires very heavy Commonwealth Government involvement because the Commonwealth Bank of Australia will be one of the tenderers for the State Bank. According to Mr Keating, to meet the financing requirements of that, the proposal will be that the Commonwealth Bank itself be privatised up to the level of 49 per cent.

I ask Senator Button a couple of questions that I hope he will answer in his remarks. If the Commonwealth Government wanted to bail out Victoria, which is entirely what this matter is about, then why did it not provide the money in the Budget brought down in this Parliament less than three days ago? Why did it not have the guts to tell the Australian people that Victoria was bankrupt, that Victoria was broke and that it would help bail out its mates in Victoria?

The Government did not have the guts to do that for one reason. It would have smashed the integrity and credibility-not that any exists any longer-of both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and, more particularly, the Treasurer and would have thwarted once and for all the Treasurer's unbridled prime ministerial ambitions.

How does Senator Button, the decent man sitting opposite who leads the Government in this chamber, feel about that? In the last couple of days questions have been asked of him relating to financial dealings in which the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have been involved. Senator Button is the third most senior member in this Government and he did not have a clue. He has been deliberately excluded from the counsels of this Government on matters of high finance and issues affecting every Australian.

I want Senator Button today to try to untangle a little the web of the amazing confusion that he in the Senate and the Treasurer in the House of Representatives have caused in the last 24 hours. They have a complete inability to get a consistent act together in terms of the questions asked of them of their knowledge of and involvement in the matters pertaining to the Pyramid Building Society in Victoria and the role of the Reserve Bank of Australia.

On the question of the role of the Reserve Bank, I believe that the Government in its financial dealings in recent weeks and months has prostituted the role of the Reserve Bank. It has politicised the Reserve Bank. The bank is one of the basic institutions of this country. The Government has undermined people's confidence in the integrity of the bank in a way that is very damaging indeed to the whole of this nation and the whole of our financial structure.

Why has the Cabinet made this decision about the Commonwealth Bank? I do not know whether Senator Button was involved in even that one. What will be the situation in the Caucus? What will be the decision by the wider Australian Labor Party? Because of the way that the Labor Party is structured, the only way that a decision to privatise the Commonwealth Bank can be taken finally is to have the approval of the Labor Party, at least at a special conference.

The Government obviously could not deliver on the Commonwealth Bank proposal quickly, if at all-and the odds are against it given the strength of the Left within the Australian Labor Party. Senator Button made this announcement today. I just ask what degree of confusion the Government and Senator Button think this will throw into the whole web of financial relations in this country?

I go back to my earlier point: this decision announced today has nothing to do with proper financial management; it has nothing to do with the proper finances of government; it has all to do with saving the neck of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer and putative Prime Minister of this country. If that is the way this country is to be run, and it is the way it has been run during the period of this Government, it is no wonder Australia has had its credit rating in the world downgraded twice-and for the first time ever in the history of this country. It is no wonder, because of the deals done between the Federal and Victorian Labor governments, that we have had a downgrading of the Victorian Government's credit rating for the first time in any State government's history.

The history of the State Bank of Victoria is unbelievable. I do not believe that the activities and developments in the State Bank of Victoria over the past year or more have been unknown to the Treasurer. I believe that the Treasurer of this Commonwealth, Mr Keating, has known of and has been involved in the negotiations concerning this matter virtually from day one. I believe that in the handling of the State Bank matter over the last 12 months there has been a total abuse of the whole processes of proper financial administration between governments and within governments.

I will leave my colleagues Senator Campbell and Senator Michael Baume to deal with this matter as it concerns other States; in my remarks today I want to concentrate on Victoria. The State Bank is only one of a series of disasters that has occurred under Vic Inc. over the period of the Cain and now Kirner Governments.

The State Bank disaster started from the day it took over the Tricontinental merchant bank in 1985. Tricontinental was the highest risk merchant bank in Australia. Why did the State Bank ever get involved in that operation? The State Bank, almost from the day that Tricontinental was taken over, found massive losses in that institution. It tried various avenues to get out of Tricontinental, to get the financing of it taken away from its ledgers. Those avenues ranged from Queensland coal companies to Japanese banks to the Australian Bank Ltd. The Australian Bank operation to take over Tricontinental was stopped only by the intervention of two independent directors on the board.

Indeed, not only did the State Bank go as far as the Australian Bank, a private bank, but it also went to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. When the losses were disclosed publicly for the first time in the middle of last year, the State Bank was technically bankrupt. Despite that, State Bank representatives went to the Commonwealth Bank for financial assistance. The Treasurer must have known about that at that time, at the very latest, and he almost certainly must have known much earlier. The State Bank had to get $300m or go insolvent. Where did the State Bank go after it had all these knock-backs from the other banks? It went to the South Australian Government and got a loan of $300m.

TALK.START.PARA: —What newspaper did you get that from?

—I got it from a variety of places but the most authoritative was the Premier of South Australia, who happens to be the leader of the Federal Labor Party. He said in the South Australian Parliament on 8 August that the deal was done. I asked Senator Button this question in Question Time earlier today, and he claimed he did not know anything about it. I am not casting aspersions on him and I do not deny that Senator Button did not know about it, but that simply proves the point that has been so patently obvious for so long: Keating and Hawke have cut him and most of the other Labor Cabinet members out of any decision- making in relation to the fundamentals of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: On 8 August in the South Australian Parliament, Premier Bannon said that the deal was done `in full consultation with, and with the approval of, the Reserve Bank'. That could only have happened with the full knowledge and connivance of the Treasurer of this Commonwealth. The Reserve Bank does not take fundamental decisions like that without consulting the Treasurer, as it made clear time and again in its annual report tabled last night.

The web of deceit that has been weaved by Labor governments-State and Federal-on the question of financial relations is unbelievable. On Wednesday night I raised in the Senate a matter which we happened to pick up from some obscure papers relating to the advances to the Minister for Finance. It related to three deals that were done during the Premiers Conference-one of them was two days before the Premiers Conference-involving $72m: $40m to Tasmania, $20m to Western Australia and $12m to South Australia. These deals were done to subvert the whole processes of the Loan Council and the Premiers Conference. They were not announced at any time by the Federal Government and, until those papers were tabled in the Senate on Wednesday, they had not been made known. Certainly, the South Australian deal had not been made known to anyone at all. I do not think that the Western Australian deal had either.

The Western Australian deal is particularly extraordinary because during the Premiers Conference the Treasurer made great play of knocking back a Western Australian claim for an additional capital grant for road purposes. Whilst the Government was doing that, so that it could escape the vision of the other Premiers, it was doing a deal out the back door to give Western Australia $20m. It gave Western Australia $20m and did not tell anyone.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in the Budget Papers.

—It is now in the Budget Papers, but it is in obscure Budget Papers. It is not in the appropriation Bills or the Budget documents that have to be legislated by this Parliament. It is in documents that come to the Parliament a lengthy period after the decisions and deals have been made.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said at the outset, we are seeing a continual process of the undermining of the fundamental institutions of this Parliament. We are seeing the same shabby deals, the same contempt for proper procedures and for all normal standards of basic conduct in the public scrutiny of public financial administration in this country as we saw 15 years ago.

I remind those honourable senators who were here at the time-there are very few left now, but Senator Button is one of them-of what happened to this country when precisely the same sort of web was woven inexorably in the period 1974 and 1975. We are seeing a Labor Government going down the path which led in 1975 to the destruction of the confidence of virtually every Australian in the process of government in this nation. If that is the way this Government wants to go, so be it, but the cost that it is imposing in terms of confidence in our basic institutions, our financial structure, our whole process of government and parliamentary democracy, is certainly the most serious since that time. I believe that it is an even more serious situation than pertained then, and that is difficult indeed to imagine.

When Senator Button responds to my remarks today I want him to answer the questions I have raised. In particular, I want him to tell this chamber why the deal that is being announced today in relation to the State Bank of Victoria is being done three days after the Federal Budget? Why was it not done in the Budget context, despite the fact that it was only half a Budget?. The other half was missing-the hole in the doughnut, as John Hewson quite rightly said last night. It was a doughnut Budget because the whole core of the Budget was missing. The core of the Budget was to be some you-beaut statements on micro-economic reform-about which this Government has not got a clue and about which it could take not one whit of action because of the deep factionalisation that has brought it almost to a standstill in terms of decision-making.

Why was that gap there the other night and yet three days later the Treasurer can come along and purport to make a statement of the nature that he has today? If anyone was going to make that statement today it should have been, it must have been, the Premier of Victoria. There are deals, there are connivances going on here. There is a basic destruction of the fabric of the institutional arrangements that have made this nation the way it is-a great nation. The Government is doing great damage to that fabric, damage that will serve Australia and the Government ill for a long time to come.
Opposition senators-Hear, hear! Good speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are happy interjections from Opposition senators. They all sing out, `Good speech'. I understand that. It is a long time since they have had anything that resembles a good speech from their side of the House. It is undoubtedly a circumstance in which they might get excited. Before we look at the details of Senator Short's speech, let me make a couple of observations about it. Senator Short, throughout his speech, confused his own most anxious hopes with reality. Senator Short's most anxious hopes are that all these things he says which are terrible are about to happen. That is a good technique in debating terms, I suppose.
—Senator Childs is going to stop it, is he?

—Senator Baume should keep out of this. He got stuck into my wife last night! Might I explain to people in the gallery that Senator Baume first suggested that I was stupid because he thought I had some money in the Pyramid Building Society. Later on he discovered that he had got his facts wrong, as usual, and that it was my wife who had some money in the Pyramid Building Society. So by implication he accused her of being stupid. I will put her on to Senator Baume and see how he gets on.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing Senator Short does is confuse facts with reality. Listen to the rhetoric at the start of his speech: `A web of mismanagement, deceit and corruption'. Senator Short was part of a government which had more Ministers acquitted by courts than any other Federal Government in the history of this country. One after another they went up on charges such as bribery and so on. He talks about deceit and corruption. Throughout the Opposition's period of government it gave succour to the Bjelke-Petersen Government in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It would seem to me that Senator Button is, in this country, attempting to impugn guilt because someone went before a court and was completely exonerated. Senator Button, in this chamber now, is attempting to impugn guilt where no guilt at all was found.
—Senator, this is a long interjection. It is not a point of order.
—I am asking for Senator Button's apology on that particular point, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—I hear it is an interjection. It is not a point of order and Senator Button can deal with it in his own way.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I remember when Senator Walters's Government was in office. One day I said to Mungo MacCallum, about a Minister who had just been on trial, `He looks a bit crook, doesn't he?'. The journalist said, `He doesn't look too well either'. That was the sort of thing that happened day after day.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Durack interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Durack, famous for keeping his palsied hand on tax avoiders throughout this country for many years, interjects here.
—Put them in the bottom drawer.

—Yes, put the tax avoiders of this country in the bottom drawer. The point I was making is that this Opposition, then in Government, gave succour to a government in Queensland in respect of which there was the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct set up to look at corruption. It ironed out a few instances of corruption. But the Opposition supported that Government throughout the Opposition's history.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short comes in here today and uses these words, `deceit and corruption'-mismanagement, yes. There is doubt that there has been mismanagement in Victoria. But deceit and corruption? Does any member of the Opposition have the guts to go out of this place and accuse the Victorian Minister of corruption? Not one of them would do it. Opposition members sit here and listen to this guy speak and allege corruption against Ministers in this Government and Victorian Ministers. But not one of them would go outside and say it. If they do it to me, I will tell them what will happen to them. They would do it in here, but they would not have the guts to do it outside this place. Not one commentator, not one Liberal politician in Victoria, has ever alleged corruption against Ministers in the Victorian Government-never. Yet Senator Short comes in here and does that today.

We talk about deals, deceit, mismanagement and corruption. Mismanagement, I concede; corruption, I do not. Senator Short ought to get his facts right, and those Opposition members who speak afterwards, if they are going to make these allegations, should get their facts right as well.

Senator Short, at the end of his speech, gave the Government a bit of a serve about micro-economic reform. One of the first micro-economic reforms that this Government engaged in was to deregulate the financial system in Australia, to admit foreign banks.

TALK.START.PARA: —An 83c dollar.

—An 83c dollar, says Senator Archer. Why did industries go to the wall through the period of the Fraser Government? They did so because of an artificially overvalued dollar. Everybody knows that. But one of the first micro-economic reforms this Government introduced was to float the dollar and deregulate the financial sector. That was a micro-economic reform about which a former Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, is on record as saying that a conservative government did not have the guts to implement, in spite of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System commissioned by the Fraser Government. The Opposition got all of the reports. It was not game to do it. We did it, and every economist and financial commentator in Australia applauded us for that. I want to come back to that point in a minute when I deal with some of Senator Short's wilder allegations.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, what did the Opposition do about the tax system except leave us with a system like a gruyere cheese-riddled with holes, loopholes, and the capacity for tax avoidance by the rich. That is what the Opposition left us with. The tax system has been tightened by this Government and every commentator knows it. Senator Short wants me to respond to some specific allegations he makes about Victoria. He is peculiarly excited about the fact that the State Bank of Victoria is up for sale. That has been a matter of common knowledge in Victoria for some days. Where does the Commonwealth Government get involved in that? The State Bank of Victoria is up for sale. There are, as I understand it, a number of bidders from the private banking sector for the State Bank of Victoria. The Commonwealth Government, as the principal shareholder in the Commonwealth Bank, has made a decision that the Commonwealth Bank might also bid for that bank. I would not get too excited about that. I do not think that that is cause for great excitement. Where is the deceit, the corruption and the mismanagement in that?

The Commonwealth Government has told the Commonwealth Bank that it may, like the other major banks, make a bid for the State Bank of Victoria. As the retail banking business of the Commonwealth Bank in Victoria is only eight per cent of the total retail market it is not a bad thing for the Commonwealth Bank to have access to a much larger retail market in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has Don Saunders' advice been about, making a bid for a massive loss-making operation?

—Senator Short might understand, with the passing of time, what is happening to the State Bank. If he reads his papers, he will understand the circumstances of a Commonwealth Bank offer and offers by other banks. It is not a matter which I can canvass here at the present time.
—Paul hasn't told you.

—Senator Short says Paul has not told me. That leads me to his other point: that I am somehow kept in the dark by my Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about a number of decisions which were made or not made in respect of the Pyramid Building Society. I was asked, by Senator Short's Victorian colleague Senator Kemp, what I knew about the Pyramid Building Society problems prior to 13 February. My answer to the Senate was `Nothing'-except, of course, what we had all read in the newspapers, which was described at the time as scuttlebutt emanating from some of the banks.
—But you didn't know anything about it yesterday.
—Read the Hansard, old chap.
—I have read your four goes at getting it right and you have not got it right yet.

—For Senator Short's benefit I will give the answer I gave yesterday and again today. Did I know anything about it prior to 13 February?-no. Did the Treasurer know anything about it prior to 13 February?-no. Did we, as a Government, have discussions with the two Ministers in Victoria who put out the statement on 13 February?-no. We did not participate in that. Senator Short can sit here day after day trying to develop his own private conspiracy theories about what happened, but he will not get anywhere. One of the problems which those opposite confront is that the rubbish and rhetoric of the kind that Senator Short gave forth in his speech does not deal with truth. They have to confront the truth about what has happened. It is all very well for those opposite to invent conspiracy theories but they had better at some stage confront the truth on these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the micro-economic reforms introduced by this Government was, of course, the deregulation of the financial sector. I have followed with some interest the consequences of the deregulation of the financial sector in Australia. So has the world. In no way would this Government revisit or retreat from that decision to deregulate the financial sector. But we have to look at some of the behavioural consequences of that deregulation.

Senator Walsh, in a speech during the election campaign, made the point, with stunning simplicity, that if the banks in Australia had exercised the financial diligence and prudence which Tiny Rowland exercised when Alan Bond tried to take a bit of his company, this country would be a great deal better off. That is absolutely true, because, being a people of convict ancestry, we still have a few brigands around this place who try to sell gold bricks to everybody and who do not know how to behave in a prudential manner.

The best summary is to be obtained by reading opinions in the Japanese financial press about Australia. I do not pretend to read them in Japanese, but I do read them in translation. Again and again, newspapers such as Nihon Keizai Shimbun have made some points-more in sorrow than in anger-about the behaviour of Australian business following the deregulation of the financial sector. They have made these points time and time again and they essentially concern the fact that there have been a lot of so-called entrepreneurs in Australia who have not been content with being rich, but have wanted to become mega-rich because they have been motivated by greed. This comment, from a very respectable Japanese newspaper, is reflected in newspapers such as the Financial Times in London. These newspapers, commenting about Australia, say, `Look at the tragedy of these people who were not content to be rich; they had to become mega-rich overnight'.

There are similar comments about the Australian banking sector, concerning a lack of relationship with real industries; a willingness to lend on the basis of things such as negative pledges and so on to the high-fliers who wanted to become mega-rich overnight. These things, admittedly, are the consequences of financial deregulation. There is no doubt about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Political corruption.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance today raises the role of government in our economy, which is certainly not to plan and finance every detail of the country's economic efforts. That model has been tried in Eastern Europe and found wanting. The question arises whether the corollary is true: should governments abdicate all responsibility and leave the workings of our economy essentially to the invisible hand of the market? For those who are well off and powerful, this is a good solution. They can borrow at will, here and overseas, pushing up Australia's foreign debt, as they have done since 65 per cent of our foreign debt is due to private borrowings, turning equity into tax deductable interest, losing billions of dollars in revenue to the Australian taxpayer, and providing for them a very useful base for the argument that we must cut pensions, sickness benefit and youth support programs because we have not got enough funds. They can buy public assets-that is, assets owned by the Australian community-at bargain prices. After all, public corporations are not fashionable since they have community service obligations, and that fits in badly with the formula of return on capital ratios.

SPEECH.PARA: Cross-subsidising concessions to pensioners and people in remote areas means that other users are asked to contribute on the basis of their capacity to pay. I think that this is eminently logical in a just and fair society, but the markets contend that it is untidy; so the Government starves its utilities of capital until there is at least a superficial argument for privatisation, and the result is increased charges for domestic users.

Let us have a look at part of the record. In the United States of America, users of the telecommunications system faced a 46 per cent increase in charges within five years of the system being opened to other competitors. In the United Kingdom, charges increased by 25 per cent between 1986 and 1987, following privatisation in 1984.

There are other benefits to the rich and powerful. They can buy and sell other entities at will, establishing new monopolies with little interference from a largely lame duck Trade Practices Act. In the heyday of deregulation in which we now live, when they get into trouble they can sell Australian farms, factories and forests to foreign interests-once again, with minimal interference from the toothless Foreign Investment Review Board.

The losses to Australian taxpayers emerging from this thumbnail sketch of wholesale deregulation-a Government policy which is supported by the Opposition-are high interest rates for home buyers and small businesses, with a 46 per cent rise in bankruptcies in Victoria during the past year alone, and a massive loss of tax revenue, with major entrepreneurial companies paying minimal company tax on their real profits and a consequent reduction of community services due to lack of funds.

Last year, Industrial Equity Ltd, one of our foremost industrial companies, paid 4.6 per cent company tax, against the 39 per cent that it should have paid, and it is by no means the leader in a long list of our major companies that have managed to bring down their tax liabilities at the expense of the Australian taxpayer.

As has been said, there is growing pressure to reduce the number of public utilities providing essential services. In other words, we are now starting to use assets to pay current expenses-with a consequent reduction in the Government's ability to influence public policy in the private sector and to enforce standards of safety and financial responsibility in the various sectors of industry and commerce.

Let us look at how that can work. The Commonwealth Bank is currently in line for privatisation. When we look at its behaviour compared with that of the private banks we find that it was always the last to raise its interest rates and the first to drop them. That is an example of how public policy can be introduced as a leading agent into the private sector.

The growing transfer to foreign investors of our productive capacity is placing the decisions affecting Australians in the future in board rooms in Tokyo, New York and London and is mortgaging our future. This year, we are remitting $11 billion-56 per cent of our current account-in interest. This equates to 20 per cent of our total export income. If that curve continues, in five years time we will certainly be able to confirm that we have arrived in a banana republic.

The Australian Democrats believe that the Government's real failure and the greatest loss to taxpayers was the ideological surrender to deregulation. I am sorry, but I cannot agree with my friend, Senator John Button, who has turned out to be such a staunch advocate of deregulation. I wish that he would recant and turn back from a path that is further mortgaging the future of Australians.

The way to regain control over our destiny is to give more power to the Trade Practices Commission to protect the Australian consumer, to the Foreign Investment Review Board to slow down the fire sale and to the Prices Surveillance Authority to make sure that Australians, and not just companies, get a fair deal. This is part of the Democrats' concept of the role of government in the economy-to provide a legislative framework to stimulate and support economic activity and to ensure that the consumer is protected.

I know that it is not fashionable in this chamber to say a kind word about the Cain Government, but that government accepted this responsibility. It showed-if by nothing else, then by its record of job creation, which is still ahead of that of the other States-that the direction it took was right. But, clearly, the execution was miserable. That government certainly failed in its management, and that is on the record.

The record is well and truly on the table and I will not repeat it, except to say that there is actually an example in Australia of a body which shows that government or public enterprises need not be inefficient, mismanaged or negligent. Recently the State Electricity Commission in Victoria in a six-month period shed 3,000 jobs, increased efficiency by about 6 per cent, and is now able to keep prices at a level less than the inflation rate. It is quite clearly a matter of management.

There are a number of other areas in which we feel that the Government must take the initiative and provide not only the framework but also the positive encouragement of our industry and of our community to achieve the sort of society we want to live in.

I turn to the taxation system and the tax avoidance rorts which are still with us. To be fair, the Government has done a reasonable amount to tighten the tax system, but many rorts, most of them exploitable only by the rich, still remain. The worst of these, the so-called foreign loans rort, not only hurts taxpayers by increasing their burden but also worsens the current account deficit which induces the Government, in its mistaken policy, to keep interest rates much higher than they should be.

There are many other schemes. Negative gearing, essentially involving huge company takeovers, costs billions of dollars every year. There are various rorts minimising capital gains which, again, cost hundreds of millions of dollars. The Pitt Street farmers who pass themselves off as primary producers cost the taxpayer at least $50m a year. The evasion of interest withholding tax was recently estimated by the Australian Taxation Office itself in its evidence to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, the Martin Committee, to be well over $100m a year. Income splitting using trusts robs ordinary taxpayers who do not use that particular avenue of well over $100m per year. It is one scheme on which the Government should have acted long ago; it is one on which we intend to take action. Tax havens have been only partially and very sensitively regulated against. There is also the incorporation of businesses to avoid the maximum personal tax rate.

There are other areas in which we feel that the Government, State governments, and the economy need more legislation. I emphasise to Senator Button that not less, but more, regulation is needed. We need federal legislation to control all financial institutions including building societies, friendly societies and investment trusts. It is interesting to note that the Financial Corporations Act 1974 has remained unproclaimed to this day. If it had been proclaimed then it is quite possible that we would not have been faced with the Pyramid Building Society disaster in Victoria.

We would also advocate controls on overseas borrowings by private corporations for loans above certain limits. I really do not see why we should allow private corporations to damage the public interest by establishing paper empires which, in turn, damage the savings of investors. We want increased powers and resources for the Prices Justification Tribunal-that was a slip of the tongue, but maybe it was an intentional one; it is now called the Prices Surveillance Authority. The Prices Justification Tribunal was actually so called during the Whitlam Government years, and perhaps in some of these areas we should return to those days.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly where you would take us.

—Perhaps Senator Walsh's conscience is stirring. Certainly, we feel that the Prices Surveillance Authority should take some effective action in the area of the widening margin between the cost of funds to the banks and the rates they charge when they lend those funds.

SPEECH.PARA: We certainly want more Commonwealth Government regulation and/or more direct intervention in determining interest rates for home buyers, small business and consumer credits. We have the slightly outlandish notion that the small people in this community should be protected and should be given a chance to work and to achieve an existence of their own choosing. We also need to have some legislative framework that protects them against the big boys who are not in any way reluctant to exercise their power for their own profit. Product liability in this area is long overdue. It is another initiative that we will tackle in this term.

There are a number of other areas where we feel that this Government and the State governments need to take urgent action to ensure that the sort of financial mismanagement due to lack of financial control which we have been experiencing in Victoria and in other States does not happen again.

I turn to the area of corporate law reform. We believe that there should be quarterly reports and six-monthly balance sheets for listed companies. We believe that all key financial indicators should be standardised and that there should be mandatory cash flow reporting, as is the case in the United States. In particular, we want transactions involving directors and related parties to be on the public record and to be subject to an auditor's statement. That has become the subject of some of the company disasters which we have witnessed. We want management fees open to public scrutiny on an agreed formula.

We also want future tax benefits not to be carried forward as an asset in the accounts of business, which has happened on a number of occasions, giving potential and actual investors a totally illusory picture of the health of their own investments. Strangely enough, we believe that capital formation should be given a boost in Australia rather than us going cap in hand to foreign financiers who then dictate our economic policy. We believe that we should give savings--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are here today to talk about the actions of the Hawke-Keating Government and State Labor governments which have caused massive losses of taxpayers' money through gross financial mismanagement. Coming from Western Australia none of this is new to me. We have certainly, in the words of Senator Short, suffered gross financial mismanagement, deceit and corruption in Western Australia. It is very hard to walk outside this Parliament, as Senator Button said earlier, and talk about deceit and corruption, but I would think that the proper course of action in Western Australia is to have a royal commission and have it all out in the open for once.

SPEECH.PARA: The beginnings of this mismanagement, deceit and corruption in Western Australia was started by Brian Burke, now the Ambassador to Ireland-he was sent over there by his mate Bob Hawke, the Prime Minister, and his cronies. I think it goes deeper than that, though. Senator Spindler referred to it in his speech when he suggested that we should go back to the Whitlam years. I suggest to the Senate today that indeed we may be going back to the Whitlam years. We are looking at finding money off Budget, looking at doing deals between government instrumentalities-for instance, the Commonwealth Bank and the State Bank of Victoria, as is the case today.

We are trying to find things off Budget. We are trying to keep things out of the eyes of public scrutiny. It would seem to me that the Commonwealth Government is now beginning to get involved. Its involvement is being unveiled. Perhaps that is why this matter has been brought on today.

I turn back to Western Australia. The history of the Burke Government was quickly wallpapered over for the purposes of the State election with, as I said, former Premier Burke being sent off to Ireland and the Holy See. Peter Dowding, of the local Western Australian Labor Party, was installed to wallpaper over the problems. But, of course, that wallpaper could not stick for very long, because when the walls start tumbling down and the bricks start falling apart the wallpaper is not going to last very long.

Of course, when that started happening the Western Australian Labor Party-and I am sure Senator Walsh was part of this-had to find some slightly stronger wallpaper just to try to save itself from electoral annihilation in Western Australia in the Federal election. So it put in Premier Carmen Lawrence to try to save things for a few weeks. I am sure that the Carmen Lawrence solution of veneering over the deep problems of mismanagement, deceit and corruption in Western Australia cannot last long. Sooner or later there will be an inquiry or royal commission, the truth will come out and the deceit and corruption will be uncovered. Putting Premier Joan Kirner in place of Premier Cain is another example of trying to wallpaper over deep cracks in the fabric of the Victorian financial establishment. Of course, it is pretty hard to stick wallpaper over a wall that has already fallen down. I suggest to Senate that that is what has happened here.

How did all this start, what is the cause of it and what is the real problem? The problem is that we have political interference and manipulation of these public authorities and public financial institutions. Perhaps the fact that they are publicly owned opens them to that sort of manipulation and those sorts of problems. Back in March 1983 honourable senators will recall that Malcolm Fraser said to the voters of Australia, `Your money might be safer under your bed'. I am sure that people in Western Australia who had money in the Teachers Credit Society Ltd or Rothwells Ltd or Victorians who had their money in Pyramid Building Society would probably think back on that statement of the former Prime Minister and agree with him.

In 1983, shortly after then, Brian Burke was elected as Premier, and soon after started the insipid placing of Labor political stooges into some of our great financial institutions in Western Australia. An interesting case of this is the State Government Insurance Office (SGIO), which was formed after an inquiry which was set up by Brian Burke. He appointed none other than Laurie Connell of L. R. Connell and Associates to look into the SGIO and the Motor Vehicle Investment Trust and suggest a restructuring. Of course, the State Government Insurance Corporation (SGIC) was formed, and the history of that corporation since that day is a sad and sorry one.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's the same Laurie Connell that this Government put on the National Gallery Board.
—I am reminded that Laurie Connell's engagements on government boards and various things would fill a very big book.
—Tell us about Denis Horgan.

—You tell us about Denis Horgan. The SGIC has been involved with some of the major losses that have been included in the WA Inc. disaster. After Laurie Connell recommended its formation and structure, WA Inc. was one of the beneficiaries of the SGIC when things started hitting the wall in 1987, 1988 and 1989. The Rural and Industries (R and I) Bank of Western Australia is another institution. For honourable senators who do not know, it is the State bank in Western Australia. It has been used to bail out one of the early victims of WA Inc., and that cost the R and I Bank, the State bank of Western Australia, $129m. Here is another classic example of a State government owned institution getting involved through political manipulation or having political interference in the State government and government financial institutions. In the last financial year, after that bail-out, the R and I Bank recorded a loss of $98m, the first loss in its history.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to inform the Senate of some other losses and the involvement of the State Government Insurance Commission, the R and I Bank, the Government Employees Superannuation Board and the now infamous Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd (PICL) project and refer to the impact of those on the people of Western Australia. Sooner or later someone has to pay for it all. We are suggesting that the people of Victoria will pay very heavily. The people of Western Australia are already paying very heavily and, as the Commonwealth Government now seems to be getting deeply involved in these disasters in Labor governed States, other people of Australia will pay, and pay dearly. We are already paying dearly in terms of international credibility.

I will run through some of the losses. The losses related to the bail-out of Rothwells Ltd by the State Government through various deposits from the SGIC came to a total of $147.9m. The payments made by WA Government Holdings in relation to the petrochemical project, or so-called PICL, totalled $393.3m. All this was done through the SGIC in Government payments to WA Government Holdings and various loans from the SGIC and associated bodies. Of course the State government superannuation board, where thousands upon thousands of State government employees have their superannuation tied up, had a total loss in various transactions, including revaluation of shares, debentures, and various other dubious investments to bail out other mismanagement, of $146.4m.

There were many others. In the Midland Abattoir scandal there was about half a million dollars difference between the sale price and the valuation. On the Perth Technical College site, again where Laurie Connell was involved with the Government and the SGIC, there was another $6.6m. The Teachers Credit Society, to which I have already referred, had a $129.6m loss.

As I go through these losses, we must remember that someone has to pay for them. Of course, it will be the taxpayers of Western Australia and Australia as a whole. In the Fremantle Gas and Coke deal, the State Electricity Commission of Western Australia (SECWA) bought out one of the Government's mates at a price about $15.9m above valuation. There have been various other losses: the Silicon Smelter project; the Gold Corporation statutory authority; the WA Government Holdings losses between 1983 and 1988 which amounted to another $4.3m; Swan Building Society and also the Local Government Superannuation Board. All those miscellaneous items add up to $195.2m. The total funds lost without any doubt or fudging of figures is at least $882m. There are further funds at risk, some quite substantial figures which, when all the bills come in over the next couple of years, could add up to at least $1.3 billion.

It is a fairly sad and sorry balance sheet for Western Australia. It would seem that per capita the events in Western Australia are far worse than those in Victoria. That is hard to imagine, but I guess people in the eastern States have not been overly exposed to that sad state of affairs. The effect of those losses is that the people of Western Australia are now already paying through higher taxes and charges, increases above the level of inflation, quite severe cuts in government services, and a capital works program that has almost totally ground to a halt which will see the infrastructure of Western Australia wind down to an appalling degree.

A classic example of the capital works program and a case where the Commonwealth is implicitly involved is in handing over the secret $20m for roads. That was done off the records, behind closed doors at the Premiers Conference in June. I believe that is just the tip of the iceberg in relation to this Commonwealth Government's involvement.

I conclude by saying that in Western Australia these off-the-budget and behind-closed-doors deals without public and parliamentary scrutiny are the cause of a serious problem. The Liberal Party of Western Australia and, indeed, the coalition parties in Western Australia would like to see a royal commission established to uncover the truth of this matter. If there has been no deceit and no corruption, that is good and that will rebuild confidence in the State of Western Australia, and indeed in Australia as a whole.

A lot of the people who were involved in these deals have escaped any scrutiny. Brian Burke, the former Premier, is in Ireland as an ambassador appointed by this Government. Peter Dowding is over in Sydney, and I believe that David Parker is in Hong Kong. A lot of people who have been closely involved have so far escaped scrutiny for their involvement in these deals. Of course, a royal commission would put them under that scrutiny.

There are other people, of course, in the private sector. After reading the West Australian this morning I am reminded that one Tom Forrest Hugall is now behind bars for his part in only one small section of the WA Inc. scandal. In the West Australian of Thursday, 23 August prosecutor Ron Davies, QC, said there was an immense need to deter people from this type of dishonest business dealing.

Of course, Tom Forrest Hugall, who is now in gaol, is only the tip of the iceberg. He has had to stand trial. He has had to come under public scrutiny and the scrutiny of courts, but what about all these people who have not?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there an extradition deal with Ireland yet, following Trimbole?
—I hope so. I will be looking at the extradition Bill when it comes into the Senate in a few weeks time. I certainly hope there is.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that we understand that Western Australia's problems and Victoria's problems are well documented. Today, in this discussion of a matter of public importance, the Opposition is drawing public attention to the seriousness of the Commonwealth getting involved in bailing them out. It would seem that the late announcement that the Government will now be selling 49 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank may be a way of funding a bail-out of the problems in Victoria.

The final point I would make is that the Federal Government over the last year or so, and as recently announced in the Budget, is spending somewhere in the order of $200m to set up this new Australian Securities Commission to strengthen and centralise the national corporate watchdog and to take away all of the corporate affairs powers from the States.

The Government is doing this to try to get rid of the so-called corrupt business dealings, to get rid of shonky public companies and to bring directors to more account. So, we are spending a couple of hundred million dollars there hopefully-and I honestly pray it will happen-to increase the confidence in Australia of the world community.

None of this $200m will help Australia's credibility in the international scene unless these shonky dealings between governments at the State and Federal level are fixed up first. That is what I pray will happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, when Senator Spindler was speaking he said, in effect, `We know the way they managed the economy in eastern Europe didn't work, so nobody wants to do that any more'. Then I thought he gave us a prescription for managing the economy in exactly that way. I found it difficult, I must say, to detect any substantial difference between the economic management systems applied in eastern Europe and the one which Senator Spindler was advocating.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I want to make a qualified apology to the Democrats and correct an error of fact. For many, many years I have habitually described the Democrats as totally useless people who just waste time and space. I want to make a limited correction to that because this week the Democrats did something very useful. They blackballed Senator Crichton-Browne. Consequently, he is not Deputy President of the Senate. I want to put that qualified apology on the record.

When I looked at the terms of this matter of public importance, it reminded me that I had been noticing for some time symptoms of the softening of the brain in members of the Liberal Party. This discussion has provided significant confirmation for that view. The matter of public importance states:
The actions of the Hawke/Keating Government and State Labor Governments which have caused massive losses of taxpayers' money through gross financial mismanagement.

I did not hear all of Senator Short's speech; I did hear all of Senator Campbell's. We have heard wild allegations of deceit and corruption, with absolutely no evidence to back them up. In Senator Campbell's case, the clinching evidence so far as he was concerned was that sooner or later it would be shown that the Commonwealth Government was a party to and an active participant, at least a supporting player, in some of the mistakes a couple of State Labor governments have made.

Looking at the speakers that the Opposition has put up, I would like to say something about their qualifications. Senator Short was speaking about 1975 at one stage. Of course, he then worked in the Treasury. Some people allege that he had a different name at that stage. Some people allege his name in those days was Mr Williams. But I know that he vehemently denies that, and I am in no position to pass judgment on it. However, he was perspicacious enough to realise that he did not have much of a future in the Treasury, so he won the seat of Ballarat and then sat in the Parliament throughout most of the Fraser Government years. I might come back to that if I have time.

I do not know what Senator Campbell's qualifications to speak on the matter are but, of course, Senator Michael Baume, as a former member of Patrick Partners, ought to know a great deal about gross financial mismanagement. But what they have failed to do so far-and I am supremely confident that Senator Baume will also fail to do-is provide any evidence whatsoever, other than their own conspiracy theories, about the alleged involvement of the Federal Labor Government in some of the errors that may or may not have been committed in a few Labor States. So the symptoms of brain softening are still there.

Senator Button has already made the point, of course, that somebody who sat in the Fraser Government for most of its years, as Senator Short did, does have a bit of a cheek to be moving a motion such as the one he has moved today. He did not seem to be unduly concerned about the Ministry of the Fraser years when, as Senator Button said, people used to say at that stage that this was the cleanest Ministry in Australian history because they had all been acquitted. I must say in that respect that the former Deputy Leader of the National Party certainly was acquitted. The presiding judge of the trial, whose name was Staunton, virtually directed the jury to find him not guilty, and seven hours later the jury did.

Of course, we all know the history of the Fraser Government on financial mismanagement. It came in and was going to clean everything up. It was going to get rid of inflation. It was going to end the secret tax of inflation, which was Malcolm Fraser's way of describing what other people might have called fiscal drag or bracket creep. It was going to reduce the size of government.

Of course, as I pointed out-outside the House I might say-a few weeks ago, the Fraser regime in the end welched on all the fundamental commitments that it had made at the time it came into government. It left the finances of the Commonwealth Government probably in the biggest mess they have ever been in. It left the incoming Federal Government in March 1983 with a prospective Budget deficit of almost 5 per cent of gross domestic product. As former Senator Stone's note pungently pointed out to the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, there was 11 per cent inflation, 10 per cent unemployment and a $10 billion Budget deficit-the big trifecta.

I also understand-I said earlier that I did not, unfortunately, hear all of Senator Short's speech-that, in amongst all the other wild allegations about corruption and deceit and so on, he attempted an exercise that was forcibly tried by the Opposition Leader in South Australia. He attempted to plant the story that the Bank of South Australia was in some way connected with the State Bank of Victoria.

He ought to know by now, since it has been corrected publicly, that the South Australian finance authority did buy some notes issued by the State Bank of Victoria, but the State Bank of South Australia had no connection with that whatsoever or, at least, as far as is known. He must know that, but it did not stop him trying to rerun the furphy that the Liberal Party Leader in South Australia had first tried to run 16 days ago, which I suppose is consistent with the quality of his speech in general.

—Mr Deputy President, I have another point of order. In response to Senator Walsh, he is linking all of this directly with a member of this chamber whom he has named, and it is a direct reflection on the integrity of that person.
—At this stage I cannot see any point of order. I ask you to continue, Senator Walsh. I will be listening carefully.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Perhaps I should explain. I did name Senator Crichton-Browne; I said he was a significant shareholder in Burrell Investments, which had done some insider trading in Poseidon shares. All that has long been a matter of public record. When Senator Short objected I was talking about the president of the Stock Exchange in Perth in 1974, who had no association, to my knowledge, with Senator Crichton-Browne. But perhaps Senator Short knows something that I do not.

SPEECH.PARA: The president of the Stock Exchange was revealed in the Rae report in 1974 as having been up to his ears in insider trading in Poseidon shares a few years earlier, and he remained the president of the stock exchange. One would have thought he would have been sacked, or removed, or would have had the decency to resign the day the Rae report became public. But no, he stayed there and saw out his term which, if I remember correctly, was another six or eight months.

This is a bloke whom most people would describe, quite reasonably, as a crook. He was up to his ears in insider trading because he had privileged information about a mining strike. He not only did this but also was allowed to remain president of the Stock Exchange of Perth after the fact that he had done it was made public. At the time I thought it was pretty amazing; I still think it is pretty amazing.

In the couple of minutes remaining I will make some brief observations about the deregulation of the financial system and some of its consequences. I half believe, not that it was a mistake to float the dollar and deregulate the financial system but that it probably was a mistake to deregulate it at the particular time it was done; that is, the mid-1980s when there were plenty of paper entrepreneur spivs. The easy credit that the deregulation seemed to induce at that time made it much easier for these spivs to put together their takeovers and their paper entrepreneurial empires because money was so freely available.

I was also astounded when I finally discovered-perhaps I should have known long before-the lending practices of the Australian banks, some of which Senator Button has referred to. They provided no security other than negative pledges. They did not even question these paper entrepreneurs as to how much money they owed financial institutions. I found it astounding that mainstream Australian trading banks behaved in that way.

I believe that if the financial system had been deregulated in the 1970s, as it probably should have been if the then Liberal Government had had the nerve to do so, this may not have happened. I should also put on the record that the former Governor of the Reserve Bank, with whom I once briefly discussed this, believes it would have happened no matter when the financial system was deregulated because the techniques of the negative pledges and the leverage buy-up were well known.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always interesting to listen to Senator Walsh in a debate, even though in this case he did not debate the matter before the chair, which is:

SPEECH.PARA: The actions of the Hawke/Keating Government and State Labor Governments which have caused massive losses to taxpayers money through gross financial mismanagement.

At no stage did Senator Walsh even attempt to defend, beyond saying one thing, the Federal and State governments in this scandalous situation which has developed. He claimed that we had not provided any evidence of alleged involvement of the Federal Labor Government in the errors of the State Labor governments. At least he conceded that there were errors. `Errors' is a polite word. In the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics one used to get shot for intellectual errors.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said they were crooks.

—Yes, I suppose that basically Senator Walsh indicated that they were crooks. The simple fact is that a web of corruption and incompetence has been covered up by this Government. The State Labor governments have been repeatedly bailed out and their mistakes covered up by this Government, particularly when Senator Walsh was Minister for Finance. He used the Advance to the Minister for Finance to cover up the financial incompetence, mistakes and losses of his mates in the State Labor governments.
—To do secret deals with them.

—As Senator Short says, to do the same sort of secret and dishonourable deals with them that have been exposed today and last night by the Opposition and by the State Premiers who did not get the benefit of those sleazy, slimy backdoor deals done by a government, which apparently has the same fiscal morality as the Whitlam Government in its backdoor sleazy financial deals. It has done the same sort of backdoor deals. It has also attempted to hide the sleaze and to cover up the crookedness. This is what is going on here.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that no contribution from the Labor Party has been able or intended to deny the hard core reality that in the last couple of days we have seen a secret deal entered into by the Federal Government to bail out State governments in trouble because of their own problems, because of their own, in some cases, massive incompetence-and we have yet to see the extent to which anything other than incompetence was involved. We have seen the Government bailing out its mates to the tune of $70m. Now we are seeing up to $600m going to bail out the Victorian Government in the sleazy deal which is deliberately being done off-Budget so that it will not affect the one thing that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) says he has going for him. He claims that he still has integrity. I always get concerned about people who go around the place protesting they have integrity. Keating has said that the surplus is the rock--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Baume, I reminded you early this morning that if we are talking about a member of the House of Representatives we should use the proper form of address. `Mr Keating' would be far better than `Keating'.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Mr Keating has said that `the surplus is the rock on which our whole credibility is founded'. I think he spelt the word `foundered' wrongly. His credibility sank. It is clearly sinking because of the way this sleazy deal is being done to rescue the Victorian Government. Mr Keating can say, `No, this is all above board. This is honourable. We are calling for tenders'. Let us just have a look at this process and see how phoney Mr Keating's press conference today was when he protested his innocence. He even went to the extent of saying:

SPEECH.PARA: My purpose in recommending that course of action to them was to guarantee there could be no question of the Commonwealth Government bailing out the State Government of Victoria for its problems flowing from Tricontinental.

Mr Keating set out-and will fail in the attempt-to give the appearance of not doing something that is sleazy and deceptive, but he will be doing it. The reason I say he will be doing it is evident from his own press statement.

Let us recognise that Mr Keating has to make certain that the public sector borrowing requirement (PSBR) will not be affected by any big hand-outs to Victoria because, as I noted earlier, that is the basis-the rock-on which the whole credibility of the Government is founded. Let us see.
Mr Keating claims that he was approached six or seven weeks ago by the Victorian Labor Government about these problems and the Victorian Government's desire to sell the State Bank.

We saw in the Australian Financial Review this morning one proposition floated as a way to get Commonwealth Bank control of the State Bank without affecting the PSBR, in other words, the Federal Government in one way or another selling an asset or providing funds to the State Government by an off-Budget device. That device apparently did not get up in the lengthy Cabinet meeting last night.

What Mr Keating says did happen is that the Cabinet gave an in principle agreement to allow the sale of enough of the Commonwealth Bank's capital to finance the purchase of the State Bank of Victoria-the troubled State bank of a troubled State government. For the word `troubled' we could almost substitute `bankrupt'. Certainly, in the case of the Government, it is absolutely bankrupt.

The interesting thing is that the Cabinet agreed to Mr Keating's proposal, which he says was on the basis of a request from the State Government. What Mr Keating did not tell us is whether the Commonwealth Bank itself wanted, of its own initiative, to acquire the State Bank of Victoria and whether the Commonwealth Bank thought that buying up the $3 billion in bad debts-I think the total is getting close to that-was worth the $600m-odd which is being spread around as the likely price.

I think the Parliament is entitled to know whether the Commonwealth Bank, which is supposed to be a separate statutory authority-and one would have thought it might have had some interest in this matter-is interested in acquiring the State Bank's enormous problems. But that is by the way. We have not been taken into the confidence of the Treasurer about that.

The Commonwealth Bank, like the Reserve Bank of Australia, is now being regarded by the Treasurer as one of his toys-it takes directions. Last year he arrogantly said that the Reserve Bank will do what it is told about monetary policy. In fact, the Reserve Bank did what it was told about its annual report this year. I dealt with that matter last night.
I want to express a certain degree of incredulity about the Treasurer's press statement. He stated:

. . . I believe the State Government of Victoria came to the conclusion that the State Bank of Victoria might best be sold. And as a result of that conclusion, the State Government of Victoria approached the Commonwealth Government, me in particular, with a view to the Commonwealth Bank purchasing the State Bank of Victoria. I told the representatives of the Government that, in my view, it would be very difficult for the Commonwealth Government or the Commonwealth Bank to make a judgement about the values which might be attached to the State Bank of Victoria and that the best course of action, I believe, that was open to the State Bank would be for it to offer the State Bank widely among other financial institutions. Now, this they readily agreed would be the best course of action and they commissioned Meryll Lynch to draw up documents and invite expressions of interest from financial institutions. That, I believe, they have done. And it is now a matter for the State Government of Victoria to decide which of those bids are in the best economic interests of Victoria.
That sounds all very rational-with one marvellous exception, because the Treasurer then said:
Now, the Commonwealth Bank is one of those bidders.

Having just previously said that it would be very difficult for the Commonwealth Bank to come to any estimation of value, he then said, `But it is making a bid anyway'. If that is the rationale for it not doing the bid straight up, for not having it, it is a nonsense-there was a hidden agenda. This Parliament wants to know the real reason. The reason Mr Keating gave was transparently phoney and dishonest. It was not a factor in that matter. No direct bid was made by the Commonwealth Bank because it was too hard for it to make a proper bid as it could not tell the value, but in fact even without the Commonwealth Bank having access to the tenders of the trading banks it could still have made some kind of rational offer. If it were an auction and one could see who the other bidders were, Mr Keating's rationalisation of his position would be capable of defence.

Surely tenders are secret. Surely tenders for a business remain the property of the person for whom the bid is being made unless there is a great deal of phoneyness and crookedness and there is no intention of having the tenders remain secret-and, in this case, no intention on the part of the Victorian State Government, at the direction of the Treasurer, to reveal to the Commonwealth Bank what the other tenders were so that the Commonwealth Bank could make an appropriate bid. If this were not so, there would be no rational explanation for the absolute garbage that the Treasurer has gone on with in this statement. It is just incredible.

Clearly there is a deliberate and determined attempt to get around the fiscal restraint the Government says it is imposing on the States. It is using a device; it is selling an asset owned by the people of Australia to provide a benefit to a particular State which, by its incompetent Labor Government, has got itself into a condition of bankruptcy. That is the simple and uncomplicated situation.

One can almost hear the campaign cry of the Labor Party at the next State elections around Australia: `Vote for us because when we lose multimillions of dollars we know that the Commonwealth Government will pay us through the back door'. I admit that they have lost one of their benefactors, Senator Walsh, who in recent years has been very kind through his Advance to the Minister for Finance. For example, on 30 June 1988-what a remarkable day!-the last possible day on which such an advance could be given in the financial year, the last possible day before the 1989 election, he provided $60m through the Advance to the Minister for Finance as capital grants for social infrastructure associated with defence installations.

The particular grant to South Australia we are complaining about now was not an unexpected grant. That is what the Advance to the Minister for Finance is supposed to be about. It was exactly the same sort of grant that had gone on for the previous two years. This kind of phoneyness, this kind of deceptive behaviour which the Premier of New South Wales has quite properly drawn to our attention in complaining bitterly about this deal, is a sleazy attempt to bail out the Labor Party's mates in governments which have been proven to be a mixture of incompetence and corruption.

The whole approach of the Labor Party through these problems is either to deny that the problem exists-that is usually the Keating approach: `There is no such problem; we are on track'-or if there is criticism, to silence it, as we have seen in the Reserve Bank of Australia. The Government silenced the Reserve Bank's independence when it coped with extraordinary circumstances last year-they are even worse this year-by putting out an extraordinarily frank annual report. If there are critics, silence them. If there is someone who can be used as a fall guy, sack him. Look at the former Premier of Western Australia, who suddenly disappeared. Mr Cain, obviously, is another fall guy. The Government is pretty good at finding them, even if it has no idea about how to solve the real problems. If there is a political disaster, just kill it off. If there is a failure or some corruption, hide it. That is what this debate is all about. There is so much evidence of disgraceful Government mismanagement that this discussion is needed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I table the report of the Committee on proposals for variations of the plan of layout of the city of Canberra and its environs-variations 1990-91. I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I wish briefly to refer to the recommendations that are contained therein. In particular, I mention the link road between Gungahlin and Mitchell and the necessity, because of the problems that the Mitchell traders have had waiting for Gungahlin, that that be done as soon as possible. I also refer to the matter of the speed of traffic in Bateman Street and Learmonth Drive. In relation to that recommendation, I seek leave to incorporate a tabling statement.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Report on Proposals for Variations of the Plan of Layout of the City of Canberra and Its Environs-Variations 1990/1

I refer to variation 6-Kambah Gleneagles Estate development and draw the Senate's attention to paragraph 1.14 on page 4 of the report and the Committee's recommendation that measures to control the volume and speed of traffic in Bateman Street and Learmonth Drive be introduced.
I would like to say at the outset that I believe Gleneagles is a very impressive development.
It has considerable potential to enhance the property values of proximate residential areas.
However, problems have been identified in relation to the proposed access to Gleneagles, which could have a negative impact on neighbouring suburbs.
I have been contacted by a large number of residents of Kambah who expressed concern at the proposal that Learmonth Drive and Bateman Street be the access route to the Gleneagles development.
With the development of the Hyperdome in Tuggeranong these streets have already seen an increase in traffic estimated, by residents, to be around double.

The Learmonth Drive, Bateman Street, Boddington Circuit route is attractive to motorists within to avoid traffic light control and is used not just by Hyperdome shoppers and Tuggeranong workers but by those travelling to and from the southern suburbs of Tuggeranong, to Lanyon, Cooma and the snowfields and to Queanbeyan, via Isabella Drive.
Naturally this increased volume of traffic has had an adverse impact on residents of these streets.
Problems include-
noise (causing sleep disturbance)
air pollution
dust
hazards in moving motor vehicles in and out of driveways
hazards in exiting from side streets
potential for injury or death to the aged
and potential for injury or death to children (cycling, playing or those who have to cross the road to and from school or when visiting friends).

Estimates indicate that that part of the Gleneagles development which is proposed to exit via Learmonth Drive and Bateman Street would increase traffic volumes by a minimum of 400 vehicles a day, further reducing the amenity, safety and property values of the surrounding environment.

One suggestion put forward by Kambah residents was for an alternative route onto the Kambah Pool road. However, I understand from correspondence with the ACT Chief Minister that there are a number of practical impediments to this course of action.

I have had a number of meetings with the residents of the area who have stressed that they have no objections to the concept of the development-their legitimate objection is to the impact it will have on already heavily used roads in their neighbourhood.
Late last year I contacted the Woden Valley police to discuss the issue of speeding traffic on these roads and obtained an undertaking that the area would be monitored.

In February I was advised that between 31 January and 5 February, members of the AFP Central Traffic Branch conducted a traficomp survey in Bateman Street. A total of 6,368 vehicles were recorded as having travelled in the street. Statistics indicated there was some evidence of speeding vehicles, and the AFP undertook to give attention to the street with police patrols.

I also wrote to the ACT Department of Transport to put it to them that a roundabout or speed humps might assist in keeping traffic speeds to the legal and safe limit, and I corresponded with the ACT Chief Minister, Mr Kaine, on the matter.
As a result of these representations, the Transport Policy Branch carried out official traffic counts over a two-week period in late February and early March, on the streets in question.
I recently received a letter from Transport Policy Branch with the results of the traffic count.
It indicated that volumes had increased in the last few years, but although peak traffic was significant, it was considered to be within the volumes which would be expected for streets of this type.
It did not show evidence of motorists using these streets as alternative routes to the Hyperdome.

It acknowledged Country Club Estate would add to the volume of traffic. The Department undertook to complete further surveys when the estate is complete, and take any remedial action necessary at that time.
The letter also acknowledged traffic speeds to be relatively high and advised that action was in hand to increase enforcement of 60kph limit.
I have subsequently received correspondence giving rise to some doubts about these findings.

A resident of Kambah has indicated that at the time the traffic surveys were conducted road improvements were being made in the area and there was a noticeable decline in the traffic volume in this period.

It is claimed that every time traffic survey officers were on the streets it was the Tuesday or Wednesday of an off-pay week. This is felt to be unrepresentative. Pay week or weekend traffic volumes are much higher.
I am pursuing this with ACT Transport.

While I believe the problems in Learmonth Drive and Bateman Street arise from developments further away, I am pleased that the Committee has recognised the problem for nearby residents of the estate and look forward to seeing some action to reduce the speed of traffic travelling on these streets.
