SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will be aware that last night on the adjournment I outlined three case studies in relation to bank malpractice and bank corrupt practice. These were, in fact, further in depth illustrations of cases that I had previously outlined to the Senate and about which I tabled associated documents. This afternoon I would like to take this opportunity to put flesh on the bones of one of those cases.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, I will outline now to the Senate the saga of Huon Valley Springs Pty Ltd. The Australian Financial Review of 13 August 1990 contains a prophetic cartoon. It shows Mr Hawke standing in a puddle of mineral water holding a graph showing rising imports. Mr Keating is standing beside him with two hands and a foot in a dyke trying to stem the importation of mineral water. I will table this cartoon as one of a series of documents which I will be tabling in support of my statements on this occasion. I apologise to the Senate that there is a lot of technical and legal detail in this speech that I am making. I had sought leave to incorporate it but, unfortunately, that leave was denied so I must now proceed to outline it in full.

The cartoon which I have just tabled is rather prophetic. Our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and our Treasurer (Mr Keating) would not have been in this predicament if the mineral water processing and bottling plant of Huon Valley Springs Pty Ltd had not been crippled by fraud and corruption by bankers. In a letter dated 6 February 1986 to the Managing Director of the ICLE bank, Mr Georgie Draskovic, Mr Bruce Naghten had this to say about Huon Valley Springs:

. . . the product Huon Valley Spring Water would have to be by personal and independent assessment a product of higher quality than any other Australian and possibly international mineral waters . . .'

The bankers fraudulently stripped Huon Valley Springs of its assets, thereby depriving Australia of a world class domestic and export industry. The cartoon could have applied equally to the microwave cookware manufactured by Mighty Chef Products Pty Ltd, the steel framed housing manufactured by Tony Rigg Welding and Manufacturing Pty Ltd and many more. The cartoon is prophetic because unless the Government saves our manufacturing industries from the asset stripping operations of banks, all honourable senators may find themselves with their hands and feet in the dyke trying to stem the importation of many other products besides mineral waters.

I will now disclose to the Senate and to the Australian people at large the disgraceful saga whereby Huon Valley Springs was crippled financially, stripped of its assets and sold to predetermined parties. Honourable senators will recall that this case was one of the first three of 85 cases that I have now tabled in the Senate.

In 1985, Durna Proprietary Ltd owned land and a mineral water bottling plant in the Huon Valley, Tasmania. The directors of Durna were Anthony Sofia, Dominic Vizzone and Maxwell Reynolds. The shareholders were family companies of the directors. Mr Reynolds owned adjoining land containing a mineral water spring. The rights to the mineral waters were shared by the three family companies equally.

In September 1985 the parties signed contracts with Huon Valley Springs Pty Ltd and its proprietor, Miss Donna Batiste. Durna leased the premises containing the bottling plant to Huon Valley Springs. If Huon Valley went into receivership, Durna had the right to terminate the lease. Clause 6(a) of the agreement for the lease dated 20 September 1985 provides as follows:

(a) . . . if the Lessee . . . is placed under . . . receivership then . . . the Lessor may at any time re-enter upon the demised premises . . . and thereupon the term hereby created shall absolutely determine . . .
I seek leave to table a copy of that document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —What this means is that if Huon Valley went into receivership Durna could terminate the lease and prevent the receivers from selling the business as a going concern. That would place Durna in a favoured position to acquire the assets of Huon Valley on its own terms.

SPEECH.PARA: In September 1985 Mr Reynolds granted water rights to Miss Batiste. If Miss Batiste failed to pay the royalties, Mr Reynolds could terminate the agreement. Clause 8.1 of a Mineral Water Agreement, dated 26 September 1985, provides as follows:

. . . the Proprietor shall have the right to terminate this Indenture in the event that . . . the Grantee fail to perform any of their covenants and obligations herein contained PROVIDED THAT . . . written notice of intention to so terminate has been posted . . . and . . . the Grantee . . . have failed to rectify such breach within thirty days . . .
I seek leave to table that document in support of this statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —What this means is that if Miss Batiste failed to pay the royalties, Mr Reynolds could terminate the agreement and prevent the receivers from selling the business as a going concern. Again, that would place Durna in a favoured position to acquire the assets of Huon Valley on its own terms.

SPEECH.PARA: In September 1985, Huon Valley appointed Mr Reynolds to maintain quality control of the mineral water. Clause 12.3 of a consultancy agreement dated 26 September 1985, provides as follows:

. . . The services to be provided by the Consultant to the Company shall be-(d) to devise and implement all such procedures as may be reasonably necessary to ensure the . . . sterility of mineral water produced and bottled by the Company and to maintain the quality control of the mineral water . . .
I seek leave to table that document in support.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —What this means is that Mr Reynolds had the sole responsibility for maintaining the quality control. If Mr Reynolds failed to maintain quality control, contaminated product would have to be withdrawn from the market.

SPEECH.PARA: By mid-October 1985 plant necessary to commence operations had been installed and commissioned. Mr John J. Splatt, Managing Director of Brewers and Bottlers Trading, in a report dated 15 October 1985, reported as follows:
. . . each machine is in very good mechanical condition and . . . should settle down and perform well.
The system of product treatment and filtration appears to be quite good and . . . will be very efficient in relation to both . . . production and quality requirements.
I seek leave to table that report in support.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —What this means is that the plant was adequate to meet quality requirements. If the mineral water was contaminated, it would result from a failure of Mr Reynolds to properly discharge his duty as quality controller.

SPEECH.PARA: Production of mineral water commenced in late October 1985. The Commonwealth Trading Bank, as it then was, granted an overdraft to Huon Valley Springs. The cash flow projection, commencing in October 1985, showed that the overdraft could rise to a debit balance of about $1.2m in November, but sales of product would commence in December estimated at about $1.6m. The debit balance was to be cleared by February 1986. I seek leave to table a cash flow projection in support of that.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —What this means is that for Huon Valley Springs to meet its budget and continue to trade, the Trading Bank had to honour cheques drawn against Huon Valley's overdraft account, up to $1.2m, and Mr Reynolds had to maintain quality control so that initial sale of the product would reach $1.6m. Neither of those things happened.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Development Bank approved a loan to Huon Valley Springs of $500,00 to assist with the reimbursement of building extensions and equipment-I think that means refurbishment. The Development Bank took a registered first equitable mortgage over the assets and undertakings of Huon Valley. The equitable mortgage dated 8 November 1985 provides as follows:

2 (i) The moneys hereby secured shall at the option of the Bank . . . immediately become payable and this mortgage shall immediately become enforceable without any demand or notice in each or any of the following events:-
(a) If the Mortgagor . . . makes default in the payment of moneys hereby secured or any part thereof . . .

3. At any time the moneys hereby become payable or after this mortgage shall have become enforceable, the Bank . . . may appoint in writing any person to be receiver of the mortgaged premises . . . and such receiver so appointed shall . . . have power:
(e) to sell . . . all or any of the mortgaged premises either by public auction or private treaty . . .
I seek leave to table an extract of that equitable mortgage.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This means that if Huon Valley defaulted in the payment of any instalment, no matter how small, the Development Bank could appoint receivers without making any demand or giving any opportunity to rectify the default.

SPEECH.PARA: The application for finance, dated 1 November 1985, states:
Instalments of $8,920 covering both principal and interest are to be payable on the first Wednesday of each month of the year. The first instalment is to be met in July 1986 . . .

This meant that, all things being equal, Huon Valley would not have to service instalments of principal or interest until the overdraft account with the Trading Bank had been fully discharged and the business was profitable. The application goes on to state:
In addition to the above repayment instalments, interest charged to the account on the first Wednesday of December 1985 is to be met on the first Wednesday of January 1986.

Hence, Huon Valley was obliged to make only one payment to the Development Bank before its operations became profitable-that was a payment of $7,708.33 in the first week of January 1986. It also meant that if Huon Valley, for whatever reason, failed to pay $7,708.33 on the appointed day-whether the Development Bank had issued a reminder notice or not-the Bank could thereupon, without issuing any demand or giving any opportunity to Huon Valley to pay the money, appoint receivers to the assets and undertakings of Huon Valley. All the Development Bank had to do was wait for Huon Valley to default and then strip it of its assets. The plot is straight out of the Middle Ages! The measure has now been put in place, and the Bank has proceeded to put it into effect.
The application goes on to state:
Security is to be given to the Bank . . . and is to comprise-
(A) Registered First Mortgage by applicant over Registered Lease issued in terms of Agreement dated 26 September 1985 between Durna Pty Limited and applicant . . .

That means that the Development Bank knew about the lease and knew that if the Bank appointed receivers, Durna could terminate the lease. I seek leave to table the application for finance as annexure `H'.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Development Bank paid $350,000 of the loan funds to Huon Valley on 12 November 1985. The funds were placed on term deposit with the Trading Bank for a period of 181 days precisely, as per the term deposit lodgment authority dated that day. The funds were placed on deposit as a form of security for additional drawings on the overdraft account of Huon Valley Springs. I seek leave to table the term deposit lodgment authority.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During November 1985, Huon Valley bottled five container loads of mineral water under the quality control supervision of Maxwell Reynolds. In late November and early December 1985, these containers were shipped to Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane. It was found that each container load of product was contaminated with pieces of particle board. The pieces of masonite in the bottles were clearly visible to any casual observer. The product was manufactured over a period of at least four weeks. Throughout that period, Maxwell Reynolds was in direct personal control of the manufacturing process.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of Brewers and Bottlers Trading established that the filtration system was in order. A report to Huon Valley Springs recorded that 90 per cent of the stock shipped to Sydney was contaminated; 40 per cent of the stock shipped to Melbourne was contaminated; and 100 per cent of the stock shipped to Brisbane was contaminated. The stock was not fit for sale and was dumped. Huon Valley Springs had no hope of achieving the estimated sales for December of $1.6m. This means that the mineral water was deliberately sabotaged to cripple Huon Valley Springs. Reynolds had the opportunity and the motive to sabotage the mineral water. I seek leave to table the report from John Della Pietra as annexure `J'.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first shipment of contaminated water was dispatched to Sydney on 5 December 1985. By an extraordinary coincidence, the Trading Bank commenced to dishonour cheques drawn on the overdraft account of Huon Valley Springs on that day. Miss Batiste and the management of Huon Valley Springs did not learn of the contamination until 18 December 1985; so they could not have forewarned the bank. Maxwell Reynolds did know of the contamination. He had motive and opportunity to disclose the contamination to the bank and, hence, trigger the process of cheque dishonouring.

SPEECH.PARA: It is curious that the Trading Bank commenced to dishonour cheques drawn on the overdraft account of Huon Valley Springs on 5 December 1985. If the cheques had not been dishonoured, the debit balance of the overdraft account at the close of business on that day would have been $942,105. Every bank statement since that date, up to and including 17 January 1986, shows a debit balance far in excess of that amount. What is more curious is that, in the case of each dishonour, the cheque was debited to the account and then the transaction was reversed.

That means that the Trading Bank deliberately recorded transactions on the bank statements, discrediting the creditworthiness of Huon Valley Springs. Between 5 December 1985 and 21 January 1986 the Trading Bank recorded 234 reversals spread over 26 separate statements. Page 42 of the bank statements, issued on 27 December 1985, showed an entire page of reversals, totalling 40 in number.

What is even more extraordinary is that, when each of the 234 reversals was recorded, the Trading Bank held $350,000 on fixed deposit. No part of that sum was released by the Trading Bank to service the dishonoured cheques and, more importantly, no part of that sum was released to pay the $7,708.33 owing to the Development Bank. No part of the $350,000 was released to pay the debt of $7,708. By withholding the $350,000 the Trading Bank was responsible for Huon Valley Springs being in default under its equitable mortgage to the Development Bank. That default led to the appointment of receivers and the eventual sale of the business to a company, being a wholly owned subsidiary of Durna Pty Ltd-that is, the family company of Reynolds, the man in charge of quality control.

This means that Reynolds crippled the cash flow of Huon Valley Springs by contaminating the mineral water and the Trading Bank prevented Huon Valley Springs from recovering from Reynolds's actions by withholding the money held on deposit. Furthermore, the Trading Bank destroyed Huon Valley's creditworthiness, thereby preventing the raising of alternative finance or the negotiation of a joint venture. I seek leave to table pages 29 to 60 of the Huon Valley Springs bank statements as annexures.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Huon Valley Springs did not make the interest payment to the Development Bank and was in default under the equitable mortgage. On 8 January 1986, a meeting took place between Mr K. Robinson, Acting Assistant General Manager of the Trading Bank, Mr J. Vanner, Deputy Chief Manager, Mr K. Simington, Senior Manager, and Mr J. Cambourn, Solicitor, Legal Department, representing the Trading Bank, and Mr J. Thompson, State Manager, New South Wales, representing the Development Bank. An internal memorandum by Mr Simington dated 9 January 1986 reported on the meeting as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Mr Thompson was informed of our intention to serve demand on both the company and Miss Batiste. He said Commonwealth Development Bank would not serve demand immediately but would wait until being informed that the company proposes to cease operations. Mr Thompson mentioned that if CBA was prepared to underwrite the cost, CDB would be willing to appoint a Receiver if the CBA thought there was a possibility of the company trading out of its difficulty.

This meeting must stand as one of the most extraordinary in the annals of banking in Australia. Mr Simington, the Senior Manager to the Trading Bank, was present at that meeting. He knew that the Trading Bank held the $350,000 on interest bearing deposit. In an internal memorandum, purportedly dated 20 December 1985, Mr Simington said:
The term deposit is held as security to support advances to Huon Valley Springs Pty Ltd . . .
The Development Bank knew that the Trading Bank held the $350,000 on interest bearing deposit. On 12 November 1985 the Development Bank wrote to Huon Valley Springs as follows:
We have today presented your cheque for $350,000 to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Park and Castlereagh Streets, Sydney, New South Wales, for placement in term deposit.

That letter was signed by Mr M. H. Dublin, for the State Manager, Mr J. Thompson. Mr Thompson was at the meeting. What that means is that management at the most senior level in both banks knew of the default, knew of the $350,000, and did nothing to rectify the matter-a default relating to a mere $7,708.33. What they did was discuss receivership. No wonder Australia is the laughing stock of the world's business community.

One further matter: the Development Bank made it known that a receiver would be appointed if the company ceased operations. What that means is that Vanner and Simington had the knowledge to pass on to a party who may seek, by fraudulent means, to convince the Development Bank that the company had ceased or would cease operations.

On 17 January 1986, the Trading Bank credited $358,980.52 to the overdraft account of Huon Valley Springs. That sum represented the principal held on interest bearing deposit, $350,000, and interest thereon. The authority relied upon by the Trading Bank to appropriate the funds in reduction of the overdraft account of Huon Valley Springs is dated 13 November 1985, and reads:

We acknowledge the Bank's existing right at any time without notice to us to apply the whole or any part of the moneys payable in respect of Term Deposit referred to in Acknowledgment No. 1136360 . . . in or towards payment of any balance or balances that may stand to the debit of either or any of our following accounts . . .
The authority does not specify any account or accounts and was left blank. I seek leave to table that authority.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In other words, the authority was ineffective and the money was transferred without authority. What that means is that the Trading Bank held the funds on deposit until Huon Valley Springs was crippled and then misappropriated the money.

SPEECH.PARA: The deposit of those funds into the overdraft account meant that cheques after that date could be honoured by the Bank. That did not happen. Cheques were still dishonoured until the account was effectively frozen on 21 January 1986. That was blatant fraud. Vanner tried to cover this fraud by telling a blatant lie. In an internal memorandum, dated 20 February 1986, Vanner alleged:
. . . a decision was made to appropriate funds held on term deposit and apply such moneys to the reduction of the O/P/A (overdraft account) on 21 January 1986.
That is not what the bank statement said. To round off the Trading Bank's disgraceful treatment of Huon Valley Springs, I refer to memoranda of Simington and Vanner: Simington, 14 January 1986:
Cheques total $7,344.88 as below were held over from 13 January and will be dishonoured today unless cash funds are provided . . .
Vanner, 15 January 1986:
The hard line is to be taken. Cheques drawn on the Huon Valley Springs account are to be dishonoured . . . Batiste cannot expect otherwise and she is not worthy of some special treatment . . .

Reynolds, Vanner and Simington had sabotaged the business of Huon Valley Springs. Now the vultures made their move. Durna had applied to the ICLE Bank for finance through investment and development consultant Mr Bruce Naghten Managing Director of ABC Property Planners Pty Ltd. On the day before the Trading Bank froze Huon Valley's account, Naghten wrote to the Managing Director of the ICLE Bank, Mr Georgie Draskovic, relating to a proposed mortgage over the mineral water agreement, as follows:

. . . Donna Batiste has the expertise to promote Huon Valley Springs we perceive there are possible dangers in relation to the control of the marketing of the product which will derive the income base by way of the royalty as per volume of extraction.

The letter went on to envisage a joint venture with Miss Batiste. What this means is that, to better secure the loan from ICLE to Durna, Miss Batiste would have to relinquish control of Huon Valley Springs. I seek leave to table that letter as annexure L.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Naghten was appointed to represent the ICLE Bank and the principals of Durna, Messrs Sofia, Vizzone and Reynolds, to formulate an offer to acquire Huon Valley Springs. This was confirmed in the telex from Mr Draskovic, dated 29 January 1986. I seek leave to table the telex as Annexure M.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Naghten's strategy would be to induce the Development Bank to appoint receivers to the assets and undertakings of Huon Valley Springs and thereafter purchase those assets on terms favourable to Durna. His clients would want to take control of Huon Valley Springs Pty Ltd to utilise the name and take advantage of tax losses. That would necessitate offering a carried equity to Miss Batiste for relinquishing control of the company.

SPEECH.PARA: The Trading Bank was an unsecured creditor and stood to lose heavily from the receivership. Therefore, it would be appropriate to offer a carried equity to an affiliate of the Trading Bank and to take over the leases of the plant and equipment by the Trading Bank to Huon Valley Springs. In a memorandum from Reynolds to the Sunday Telegraph, it is recorded that an offer was to be made to Miss Batiste, as follows:

(b) that the offer would be made to Donna Batiste and that the money would come through the ICLE Bank via a group as follows: ICLE, 20 per cent; AEFC, 20 per cent; ABC, 20 per cent; D. Batiste, 10 per cent; and Durna, 30 per cent.
(c) The connection between ICLE, AEFC and the Commonwealth Bank was evident.

The reference to AEFC refers to Australian European Finance Corporation Ltd, an Australian resident merchant bank then owned by the Banca Nationale Del Lavoro of Italy and the Commonwealth Bank. The Del Lavoro Bank also owned the ICLE Bank, as per the telex from Draskovic. What this means is that AEFC was to be the affiliate of the Trading Bank to take the carried equity. I seek leave to table the memorandum in support as Annexure N.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Naghten set up the appointment of the receivers the day after the Trading Bank froze the account of Huon Valley Springs. In a letter dated 22 January 1986 from Naghten to the Deputy State Manager, Commonwealth Development Bank, Mr Bill Burton, Naghten made a number of fraudulent misrepresentations, clearly calculated to induce the Development Bank to appoint receivers. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: It has been brought to our attention that there is substantial plant and equipment leased by the Commonwealth Development Bank and there is no record of authority given by the lessor in regard to this equipment installed on lands leased by Donna Batiste.
No plant and equipment were leased by the Commonwealth Development Bank. No lands had been leased to Donna Batiste. Both of these assertions are blatant lies. The letter continues:
It has also been brought to our attention there are substantial trade creditors in excess of $650,000 who have instigated proceedings . . .
No creditors had instigated proceedings. That is another blatant lie. The letter continues:

With the awareness of the preceding points, the lessor under the terms of this lease has taken necessary action to rescind the water rights document as they believe the royalty payments due are not forthcoming.
The lessor had no right to rescind the water rights document and did not attempt to do so. This is another blatant lie. I seek leave to table that letter as annexure NA.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —What this means is that Naghten fraudulently represented to the Development Bank that the lease of the land was in jeopardy, that the water rights were in jeopardy, and the capacity of Huon Valley Springs to continue to trade was in jeopardy. These were exactly the matters which the Development Bank would rely upon to appoint receivers. For this disgraceful criminal act, Naghten should have been prosecuted with the full vigour of the law, but was not.

SPEECH.PARA: Naghten had inside information from the Commonwealth Bank. On 5 February 1986 Naghten met with one Bill Phren and Len Short, financial advisers to Huon Valley Springs. Naghten said:
How did Donna Batiste feel about having her Rolls repossessed at the Regent last night?.
Short said, `Not too good, I believe'. Naghten then said:
Then how will she feel tomorrow when the receivers from the Commonwealth Development Bank walk in and take her business? .
On 6 February 1986 Australian European Finance Corporation Ltd faxed an offer to Miss Batiste as follows:

The purchasing party also offers to purchase stock and work in progress at cost and take over plant and equipment leases on valuation. In addition to the above, a 10% equity shareholding is available to Donna Batiste at no cost in consideration of acceptance of this offer.

The offer makes no reference to servicing the debts to the Development Bank or the Trading Bank. The offer makes no reference to servicing the debts to unsecured creditors of Huon Valley Springs. The offer was nothing more than a sham made in anticipation of receivership. I seek leave to table a facsimile transmission.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 February 1986 Mr Peter Allen of Arthur Anderson attended at the offices of Huon Valley Springs. He served a letter of notice on behalf of the Development Bank. The notice demanded payment of $525,020.10 within one hour. That notice was nothing more than a sham made in anticipation of receivership and was the last link in the chain of the seizure of a business.

SPEECH.PARA: I will have to return to the final few paragraphs of this expose at a later adjournment opportunity. I thank the Senate for its patience in allowing me to put this very serious case before this chamber and, therefore, before the Australian people.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 July 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (l) Why has the invention of Mr Andre Scheitler of the Albury Base workshops, which assists a tank crew to maintain the correct relationship between the sight and the gun barrel, been shown to the Belgian and Canadian Defence Forces.
(2) What legal protection has been provided for the invention.
(3) When will it be put into service in the Australian Armoured Corps.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1981 Australia, Belgium and Canada signed a Memorandum of Understanding for the coordination of spare parts procurement and initial aid in the maintenance of the Tank Fire Control System, manufactured by SABCA in Belgium, and common to the Leopard Tank operated by the three countries. This agreement has allowed the transfer of information and technological developments between the three user nations at regular tri-partite Working Group meetings. As a result of successful trials in Australia of the device developed by Mr Scheitler to improve the Tank gun/sight relationship, it was considered that the device may also be able to be sold to Belgium and Canada, thereby creating an export market for the invention, with concomitant benefits of larger royalties for the Commonwealth, and a lower production cost for the relatively low numbers of the item required by Australia.

(2) Prior to the issue of Mr Scheitler's invention on loan to the Belgium Army for evaluation, the Commonwealth applied for, and was granted, a Belgian patent for the device. This patent is still in force. Canada has requested a loan of the invention under the auspices of the Quadripartite ABCA organization. Under this agreement, Armies of the participating nations, America, Britain, Canada and Australia, agree to make provision for the reciprocal use of materiel when such usage is in the interest of standardization. Among the conditions governing these standardization loans is the quite specific requirement that the providing Army retain ownership of all patent and manufacturing rights to the materiel.

(3) A requirement to procure 102 of the devices has been included in the Army's Six Year Minor Capital Equipment Programme, with commitment programmed in 1990/91. Deliveries of the first two prototypes are expected in 1991/92, with final deliveries of the remaining units during 1992/93.

(3) In relation to part (b) of the question, Defence Reference Book 3, Engagement of External Consultants provides instructions on the information to be provided to consultants and specifies that briefing papers and background notes provided to potential consultants when proposals are invited should normally include:
(a) terms of reference for the assignment;
(b) the main objectives-any overriding or limiting considerations of general policy should be mentioned and problems to be solved should be identified and described;
(c) specific matters to be encompassed (or not encompassed) or specific fields to be studied (or not studied);
(d) the specific tasks the sponsor wishes the consultant to undertake in logical and/or time sequence;
(e) the various skill inputs which the consultant will be expected to provide;
(f) reporting requirements;

Given these conditions, fees in excess of the accepted quote would be unlikely to be incurred. In view of the large number of contracts entered into during the time span nominated, I am not prepared to undertake a detailed examination of each individual agreement to determine if there are cases of payment of fees in excess of the consultants quote.

This was an arbitrary distance adopted for planning purposes to minimise the inconvenience of electrical interference. Any such interference, if it occurs, can be attended to and eliminated but it would be uneconomic to do this for built up areas.

(3) Radiowaves in the frequency range used by the radar have been used for short wave broadcasting since the 1930's, that is about sixty years. Experience in their use, and research findings, have led to various codes of practice related to personnel and environmental health and safety. The most important of these is Australian Standard 2772:1990 which specifies maximum safe levels of exposure to radiation. The transmitter site is planned in accordance with this standard so that all unsafe areas are contained in an inner fenced-off zone of about one hundred hectares in area.
(4, 5) Given the design standards that are being rigorously adhered to, there is no known reason to believe that there will be ill effects to health and the environment.

(6) The OTHR site search area determined in April 1988 covered the whole of the shires of Longreach, Flinders, Aramac and Ilfracombe, the majority of the shires of Dalrymple, Richmond, Winton, Isisford and Barcaldine, and small parts of the shires of Barcoo, Jericho, Blackall, Belyando, Etheridge, McKinlay and Hinchinbrook.

(7) A possible alternative location for the transmitter was identified in the Ilfracombe area some thirty kilometres east of Longreach. This locality appears to meet the very stringent terrain flatness criteria which are essential for good radar performance. However, the greater separation distance from the receiver site at Stonehenge would result in a performance penalty.

(8) Of the technologies available at this time which may be considered as alternative ways of obtaining surveillance capability (ground based microwave radar, airborne radar or satellites), there is no doubt that OTHR is the most cost effective by a large margin.
(9) In this respect it is no different to every other military installation and many civilian facilities throughout the country.

(10) Landholders affected by the buffer zones will be compensated under the provisions of the Lands Acquisition Act 1989. The amount of compensation for purchase of any land would be a matter for negotiation between the landholder and the Australian Property Group. Payment would be made at settlement.
(11) The Commonwealth would grant a long term lease to the former landholder if so desired by him.

(12) The contention that there has been a lack of consultation and negotiation is incorrect. There has been extensive consultation and negotiation with State and local government and members of the public. Information about the project has been actively promulgated through the local newspaper and radio stations. Three public meetings have been held at the Longreach Council Chambers and there have been numerous discussions with landholders and others over a period of more than a year.
